THE LAST HOUSEWIFE - Book review!

This was a highly anticipated read, particularly because I loved the last thriller by Ashley Winstead. Plus, I had seen so many amazing reviews calling it dark, disturbing, but extremely addicting. And even though I had those forewarnings, it still took me by surprise!

The story follows Shay, who’s best friend from college (Laurel) has just died, forcing her to team up with her childhood friend and current podcaster, Jamie, to face the dark past from her college days.

From the start, I was hooked. Then as the story progressed, I was even more invested. We primarily follow Shay in the present as she and Jamie work together to figure out what really happened to Laurel because with Shay’s knowledge of past happenings and Jamie’s true crime and journalistic expertise, they both sensed something strange happened. But, we also get flashbacks through Shay’s words and slowly, the truth of what happened in college comes out. Now, this is where things took that dark twist and it made me sad that these young women were manipulated in cruel ways, but also so SO angry at the powerful man who caused the damage.

And that was just the beginning because in present time, you learn that those horrific moments Shay and her friends experienced was just the start of something even worse and cult-like. Learning about it and getting into its depths was both fascinating because of the philosophy behind the whys, yet so disturbing.

I also really enjoyed the complexity and development of characters, particularly Shay and Laurel. They're not black and white at all and have so much grey with their behaviors, actions, morals. But it was written in a way that even when they did questionable things, it made you think beyond just normal rationale.

The book included a couple of twists too that I didn’t quite see coming, but also wasn’t totally surprised about. Overall, I thought it was well done because it brought out several feelings while reading and made wonder how messed up our society could be and if things like this truly exist. Read if you want a disturbing psychological thriller!

Rating: 4.5/5

⚠️: misogyny, rape, sexual assault, abuse, suicide

ONCE UPON A DECEMBER - Book review!

This was my first holiday book of the season and it definitely got me in the festive mood and had me craving all things cozy and holiday-y!

I’ve adored the Amy Reichert books I’ve read in the past, so was expecting this one to be heartwarming and sweet, but also filled with her signature foodie aspects. And that was pretty much exactly what this book was… but also with magic!

Sure, this book might’ve been a tad cheesy in some ways— Astra Noel Snow and Jack Clausen are our two MCs— and had all the elements of your typical rom com. But it was still fun!

Jack works in his family’s Kringle bakery in the Julemarked— a magical location that moves to various Christmas Markets around the world and where time is different and they only have Decembers. Over the last fifteen years, the Julemarked has made several appearances in Milwaukee where Astra and her three best friends visit as a yearly tradition. Though Jack and Astra have had multiple interactions over that time, Jack is the only one who’s remembered them, but this year he is determined to make Astra remember too so he can finally make a move.

Though it was a bit confusing to understand at first, I thought the premise of the magical Julemarked was so unique! Plus you know me and my love for books that messes with time!

Other things I enjoyed were the female friendships, Bernie the dog and the shenanigans she got into, and the holiday vibes. From the market itself to the hot chocolate and Kringle, I wanted it all.

I will also say that in some ways, the romance didn’t quite work for me. There were moments between Astra and Jack that were cute, but I think the whole time thing made it seem a little insta-lovey to me and like there might’ve been a weird age gap at one point? Jack also came off a bit selfish at times, though at the end he may have redeemed himself. Lastly, there was a trope included towards the end that I wasn’t a big fan of.

Regardless, this was still a fun and unique read to get into the holiday spirit and it was one that made you think about what you might do in Astra’s situation!

Rating: 3/5

Thanks @berkleyromance for the gifted copy!

FINLAY DONOVAN JUMPS THE GUN - Book review! Trying to keep this as broad and spoiler free as I can for those who haven’t read the whole series yet!

Finlay (and Vero) are back at it again with some of their crazy antics in this third installment of the Finlay Donovan series!

So far they’ve gotten themselves mixed up in murders, police investigations, Russian mafias, near death experiences, and more, but it’s still not over. This book, there are essentially two plot lines: 1) trying to figure out the identity of EasyClean, a hit person from the dark web and 2) paying off debts.

The setting was fun because it primarily takes place at a police academy/ bootcamp except it’s one for the community to partake in to get a taste of what the police life is like! And yes... our very own Finlay and Vero find themselves stuck here and are simultaneously trying to get the answers to their own questions while also making sure to steer clear of any potential killers.

It felt a bit like a locked room mystery because you’re presented with a cast of characters and just know that one of them is up to something shady, but you don’t know who or why. So I did enjoy that! However, where things got a murky for me was just the crossover of the two aforementioned plots. There were a few times where I got a bit confused trying to keep track of what info was relevant to what. Or even trying to understand how it all tied together.

Also, maybe it was the mood I was in while reading, but for some reason Vero’s character just seemed like a LOT. It was the same person from the previous books, but almost… amped up way more to where her actions just seemed too much for me at times. But again, could just be me being picky!

Regardless though, this book still has the same humor, laughable moments, and one liners that I enjoyed so much in the first two. Plus, we do get to see so much more of Detective Nick Anthony and that’s always a positive!

As you would expect too, this books leaves off with yet another cliffhanger so you can bet there will be more to come and I can’t wait to see how that pans out!

Rating: 3.75/5

Thank you @minotaurbooks for the gifted copy! Releases on 1/10/23!

FABLE - Book club review!

This duology (and author) has made it’s fair share of rounds on bookstagram the last couple of years & for November, my book club decided to give FABLE a go and see if it lived up to the hype!

The results? Very mixed feelings.

Let’s start with the positives! First, everyone did enjoy the concept of the story and found the initial premise to be intriguing. The world and story building was also easy enough to follow along and the story did read quickly and for the most part, kept everyone engaged as there were several of us who finished in 24 hours. There was an element of mystery in trying to figure out what Fable’s endgame is and how it ties in with Saint. Plus, out of all the characters, Saint by far seemed to be the most fleshed out and compelling and everybody was very interested in his story and background!

Now we get into some of the things that didn’t work…

As aforementioned, the idea of the story was great, however we collectively felt that the execution wasn’t quite there. While there was the overarching plot of Fable trying to reclaim her status, everything that happened in between felt a little bit like a whole lot of nothing. It was just one event after another, but it almost felt more like a checklist where once task was complete, it was forgotten and you’d move onto the next. Because of this, all the situations never felt suspenseful and it didn’t really feel like they connected to tell a greater story.

The characters themselves seemed like they could’ve been developed a bit more because we had a hard time envisioning them. And the romance is something the group is split on because some enjoyed it while others felt it came on so suddenly and in a bit of an odd fashion. (Feel free to take a stab at where I fall on this)

To sum it up, I would say that this was underwhelming, particularly for those of us who had heard such amazing things heading in. HOWEVER, I will say that this first book did leave a lot of questions unanswered and ended on a cliffhanger so despite the mixed thoughts, most of us are very curious about the second book! But also still mostly excited for SAINT which just released!

Group rating: 3/5

‘Tis the season for… Blind Date With A Book: Gifted White Elephant Style!

This was second year of putting together a this Blind Date With A Book gifting for friends and it was another success!

If you’re looking for a fun and bookish gift idea for a group whether it be a book club, friends, or family— try this!

I had a blast picking books of different genres and diversity (always nice to have variety and branch out!) to gift & then even more fun wrapping them it and writing out the clues.

When the time came to “gift” it was done white elephant style where people would go around choosing and stealing books purely based off the clues!

Pretty simple and for a book loving gift giver like myself, it was the perfect combination this holiday season! Highly recommend if you’re into this kind of thing.

TRULY DEVIOUS - Series review!

After seeing great things about this series for some time, it was finally time I got around to it!

First, I loved the private school setting of Ellingham Academy. Ellingham also isn’t your ordinary school because it’s students have unique studies, such as our MC Stevie who loves true crime and has her mind set on trying to solve the infamous Ellingham kidnapping/ murders from the 1930s. But as she continues to make discoveries, she realizes there’s more going on that what it seems…

The first book establishes a lot of the setting and characters. We meet Stevie’s classmates and friends, learn the basics of the case, and find trouble in the present. The story read quickly and was engaging because as Stevie begins to uncover some truths, we also make discoveries from the past narrative that created intriguing twists. Aside from that, there’s also the start of the storyline about a very unlikeable politician named Edward King and he seemingly has more ties to Ellingham than first imagined.

The second in the series was just as interesting as things at the school escalate even more and there definitely seems to be a killer on the grounds. Plus we get more of the Edward King saga, which I honestly wasn’t the biggest fan of since it didn’t seem to be super relevant to the greater mystery. However, that mystery of who was behind the decades old crime is finally revealed, but yet more questions seem to remain unanswered which leads perfectly into the third.

In the final book, there are even more twists and Stevie (with the help of her friends) race against a winter storm to finally put all the pieces together and the person behind the present day happenings is revealed in Hercule Poirot style and its also explained how everything has tied together. There’s again more King drama too, but I still didn’t care about that part very much.

Overall, I thought it was a quick and fun series! There’s a lot of whodunnit type of vibes and homages to Agatha Christie and Sherlock Holmes. I may not have loved it quite as much as some other similar series, but would still recommend if you like YA/ true crime/ mystery type of books!

Series rating: 4/5

LOVELIGHT FARMS - Book review!

I’m sure by now you’ve seen this book all over your feed this holiday season… so here’s another one!

I’ve seen such incredible reviews about this independently published book so I will say that I did have fairly high expectations. And while I did enjoy, I wouldn’t say I loved it and that its one of the best romances I’ve read. So, lets get into it.

I of coursed adored the setting— the small town, everybody knows everybody and their business, type of vibes + the actual Christmas tree farm of Lovelight Farms itself! Everything about that was so cozy and really just encapsulated the spirit of the holidays.

Some other things I enjoyed was the whole best friends to lovers and fake dating trope as those are two of my favorites in a romance. The relationship and banter between Stella and Luka was fun and sweet to read about it and aside from those two I also adored the other two members of the tree farm family! (Can’t wait for their stories next!)

Despite all the fun moments, there was also the plot line of saving Lovelight Farms by inviting an influencer, Evelyn, to visit and help promote it. I really liked the idea of this, however was a bit disappointed that we didn’t actually see much of this at all. Instead, the bulk of the story was just leading up to Evelyn’s arrival, but not TOO much happened once she was there and the visit didn’t seem like a focal point of the story like the synopsis made it sound like it would be.

The other reason this slightly missed the mark for me was because of the way Stella and Luka went from friends to lovers. It just sort of… happened without a whole lot of tension and angst. Plus, the way Stella seemed to deny Luka of his feelings and how blind she was to it, got a little frustrating. Lastly, I did also feel like the writing was a bit repetitive at times— I wanted to count how many times all the characters hummed under their breath…

Overall though, this was still a cute and fun holiday read that really did feel like a Hallmark movie. Perhaps my exceptions were really high on this, but I did still enjoy enough and can see why its talked about so much!

Rating: 3.5/5

OONA OUT OF ORDER - Book Review!

I have seen such positive reviews for this book ever since its release a couple of years back, especially about how it is such a great book to read while in your 20s/30... and I get why!

The premise was so fun and unique! Midnight is approaching and not only will it be a new year, but Oona will turn 19 and embark on her grand plans to travel to Europe with her boyfriend and band. However, things don’t go as planned because at the stroke of midnight, Oona finds herself disoriented and wakes up as a 51 year old (though she still has the mind and memories of being 19). Eventually Oona learns that every year on her birthday, she’ll leap to a different year of her life, meaning she’ll experience her life…out of order.

If you’ve followed my reviews long enough, you might know that I love books that talk about time travel and the intricacies of it and how it can affect things. This story was no different! While it took a leap or two for me to grasp the concept of what was happening to Oona and trying to keep track of the current, past, and future whereabouts of her, it was still so interesting to watch her experience the events of her life at different times and ages.

This story included so many fun elements like nostalgia (particularly with music) and humor to more thought provoking ones, particularly about your approach to life and how your experiences throughout the years can change your perspective on things and even make you realize you shouldn’t take things for granted. Throughout her journey, Oona definitely had both high and low points + moments  where she wanted to change her future only to realize you can’t control everything and sometimes things happen, you just have to figure out a way to get by.

I also really liked the relationship depicted between Oona and her mother, Madeline. Her mom was one of the few people privy to Oona’s annual time jumps and while it was not easy for her to manage and there were rough times, there was definitely a lot of love and support between the two.

Overall, I really enjoyed this and would definitely recommend if you’re looking for a fun but stimulating contemporary read!

Rating: 4.5/5

KISS HER ONCE FOR ME - Book review!

Another quick holiday read for the season! This queer romance had so many of my favorite tropes— fake dating, second chance, forced proximity, etc!

Last Christmas, a Portland snowstorm caused Ellie and Jack to spend the most magical day together following a bookstore meet cute. After one of the most perfect 24 hours, something happens, Ellie runs out on Jack without explanation and the two never speak again, deeming it a one night (or day) stand. Just about a year later, Ellie finds her life off track from her 10-year plan and takes up an offer with Andrew, her workplace’s landlord, to pretend a fake an engagement. But of course, this agreement leads her to meeting the Kim-Prescott family which includes his sister, Jack…

I love me a fun fake dating trope, except this one totally had a bit of a twist because it wasn’t just a love triangle between Andrew and Jack, but there was actually a love trapezoid with a fourth character, Dylan, an old friend of the siblings. The four + other Kim-Prescott family members are spending the Christmas holiday at their cabin and so much happens!

First, there was a lot of tension and build up between Ellie and Jack. Sure they tip toe around each other, but eventually they begin communicating about what happened last year and things begin to escalate (and get steamy!) between the two. But of course there’s complications since Jack cannot know about the fake engagement, so Ellie finds herself torn between what to do.

This book also had so many cozy holiday moments! From cookie baking, to caroling, to getting caught in snow storms, it made me just want to curl up with a warm blanket. I also enjoyed the themes of familial expectations and how different people handle the weight and failure and having some pretty terrible parents. But yet, still showing that family is important and how much love there is between them.

Though this book was a tad insta-lovey and did have a few too many pop song/ artist references for me (I like them, but it felt like every other page in this book), I still did enjoy it overall and it was great for the holidays!

Rating: 4/5

THE FAMILY GAME - Book review!

I was a bit hesitant to read this because I’ve had mixed experiences when it comes to this author. However, after seeing many rave reviews for it, I decided to give it a shot and was so happy I did because it was so different than her past work and so good!

The story follows Harriet (Harry) and her recent engagement to Edward Holbeck— the next in line to take over the Holbeck family’s fortune. The Holbecks are massively wealthy and privileged with their fair share of secrets. They also love their games, particularly mind games and ones that are pretty extravagant. Soon, Harry meets the family and one of its members gives her a tape to listen to and on it, Harry discovers it’s a confession to past crimes. Thus, begins the ultimate game between Harry and the Holbeck family…

The beginning felt a little on the slower side, but I think its because it helped introduce us to all the characters and establish the background to Harry, Edward, and the Holbeck’s in their entirety. However, once Harry actually got to listening to the tape and some of the games ensued (no thank you to Krampusnacht!), the pace really picked up and became more addicting!

Plus, the ending and last third or so was super explosive and intense! Another game is underway and I felt myself on edge just waiting for the dominoes to fall and everything to come together. And it did in wild fashion with a twist I didn’t quite see coming!

I will also say that there are definitely some scenes in this book that are on the darker side and not for the faint of heart as there are a couple of brief scenes that are a bit more graphic in detail. However, I think it did add to the overarching story and just haunting atmosphere of what was going on.

Lastly, the book did bring up some interesting conversations regarding power, family and just made you question the lengths one may go to protect their loved ones as well as themselves.

Overall, I was very happy with this one and would recommend if you’re looking for a quick and bingeworthy thriller! It was also perfect for winter because the events take place in the weeks leading up to Christmas!

Rating: 4/5

ALL THE DANGEROUS THINGS - Book review!

The author’s debut novel, A FLICKER IN THE DARK, was one of my favorite thrillers this last year so it's safe to say I was pretty hyped to read this and couldn’t wait to see what she did in her second!

I admittedly went in blind and am actually happy that I did! This book picks up one year after the disappearance and kidnapping of Isabelle’s son, Mason. Over the last year, the case has gone cold and Isabelle has become an insomniac as she hangs onto the belief and hope that Mason is still out there and that more work needs to be done to find him.

First, I loved the implementation of all the discussions around sleep, particularly the comparisons and contrast brought up between a sleepwalker and an insomniac— both of which Isabelle has been guilty of. There are a few chapters intermixed within the main narrative that flashback to Isabelle’s childhood where she was known as a sleepwalker. During her youth, there were quite a few incidents that took place in her household and as an adult, she’s still working on piecing together what exactly those things were.

However in present day, Isabelle is on a mission to find any clues that lead to what happened the night Mason was taken from his crib. This leads her to a true crime podcaster, Waylon, and she hopes to be able to tell her story and bring more attention to the case. As things begin to surface and Isabelle begins to grasp at the truths of what happened to her as a child, an image begins to form and you’re led to question and wonder who exactly is the dangerous person here.

Meanwhile, there’s also something going on with Isabelle’s ex-husband/ Mason’s father that seems a little suspect and at least adds another layer of complication to everything.

Though the pace at the beginning was a bit on the slower side, I did find this book to super addicting and very psychological! It made you question things and there were even a couple of twists that kept the ending exciting! Overall, would recommend if you’re looking for a solid thriller!

Rating: 4/5

LUNAR LOVE - Book review!

A sweet debut rom com with lots of food references, workplace rivalries, a love wager, and nods to Chinese culture? Sign me up!

I adored the overarching concept of this story— matchmaking vs. online dating, but where they both use the Chinese Zodiac to help match and find compatibility. Olivia has recently taken over her grandmother’s matchmaking business, Lunar Love. But in the age of online dating, she finds herself in competition with ZodiaCupid and more specifically, its handsome yet infuriating founder, Bennett.

From the first page, I knew I was going to enjoy this book! The writing was fun, there were mentions of baos and other delicious foods, a meet cute, and so much more. I also really appreciated how both Olivia and Bennett were mixed race and there were lots of discussions on identity as they both strived to truly understand their Chinese heritage, Bennett in particular. Plus being Chinese American myself, there were still so many other things I felt like I could relate to which I always love when reading.

As for the love story itself, there is definitely an enemies to lovers mindset along with the whole work rivalry piece. Combine it all and it made for some entertainment as well as funny moments between our two characters! Aside from that though, there was also a lot of talk about keeping with tradition vs. change as well as how important compatibility truly is in a relationship. While Olivia and Bennett have differing opinions, it did make for some interesting discussion!

Lastly, I just adored Bennett and found him to be such a wholesome love interest! Though admittedly there were moments (the third act conflict) where I felt like Olivia was a biiiit too rash to jump to assumptions about him and I wanted to protect him at all costs!

Sometimes I feel like I hit a rom com wall where everything feels repetitive and, but this debut absolutely exceeded any expectations I had and felt fresh! Plus it’s the perfect read to pick up with the Lunar New Year and the Year of the Rabbit just around the corner!

Rating: 4/5

Thanks so much @readforeverpub for the gifted ARC— releases 1/10/23 or snag now through BOTM!

THE VILLA - Book review!

“Inspired by Fleetwood Mac, the Manson murders, and the infamous summer Percy and Mary Shelley spent with Lord Byron at a Lake Geneva castle––the birthplace of Frankenstein––The Villa welcomes you into its deadly legacy.”

That blurb really sums up the vibes and atmosphere! The book has two timelines: 1) In the present, childhood friends and now authors, Emily and Chess, travel to Villa Aestas in Italy for some bonding and to work on their respective writing. 2) In 1974 a young woman and aspiring author, Mari, is staying at the same Villa with her boyfriend, stepsister, and two other up and coming musicians. In 1974, Pierce was murdered at the Villa which has led to questions about what actually happened. It isn’t until Emily does some digging that she begins to reveal much more and realizes things in the past seem to parallel the present.

This read quickly with alternating POVs, timelines, and even had formats like emails, news clippings, song lyrics, etc. I definitely found myself invested in the mystery of the 1974 murder and enjoyed Mari’s parts in learning about what occurred in that Villa like lots of drugs, alcohol, and sex. It was surprising to read about some of the antics, but it helped add tension to the story.

There’s also many toxic relationships in both narratives, but I liked how the author drew parallels between the two, particularly when it came to Emily and Mari. There even seemed to be a theme of women who regain power and find the strength to get out of unhealthy situations which I found interesting.

Now, the ending gave me some mixed feelings. A secret was revealed when it came to Emily and Chess’s friendship and I didn’t expect it to go that way or the resulting actions of it, thought I guess it made sense. And then there was also the twist in Mari’s story. That one I’m still really thinking on it— did I like it, did I not? But the ambiguity might be what made the conclusion so thought provoking!

Overall, it was a fast read and I think it’s my favorite by this author!

Rating: 4/5

EXES AND O’S - Book review!

Ever since I read SET ON YOU in the spring, I've been waiting for Tara’s story. I mean... she’s a book influencer!! Like what a fun and relatable nod to this space! But aside from that little tidbit, I was excited because I loved getting glimpses of Tara previously and genuinely just enjoyed this author’s writing.

As mentioned, this story follows Tara— a NICU nurse/ book influencer who has had her heart broken by guys over the years, but is still on the hunt for her happily ever after. Enter Trevor. Tatted member of the Boston Fire Department and Tara’s new roommate who has some baggage of his won. The result? Forced proximity romance with lots of tension, laughable scenes, and sweet moments!

Some things I really enjoyed was all the fun book/ trope references. If you didn’t know, prior to becoming a published author, Amy Lea was a bookstagrammer herself! So seeing those behind the scenes of Tara and diving into the bookish world through from another perspective was a blast!

I also liked how this book didn’t shy away from some deeper topics. For example, part of the premise is that Tara goes back to reconnect with her exes, hoping that one could be her second chance. Along the way it’s revealed that some of her exes saw her as “crazy”. Tara and the author vehemently argue against the use of this word to break that stigma of “crazy” women and I loved that so much! There were also other meaningful topics, particularly when it came to Trevor’s background too.

As for Trevor, he did take a bit to grow on me because he is a more complex love interest than what appears on the surface. (Plus it’s really hard to live up to Scott!) Even though I wasn’t the biggest fan of how he handled the third act breakup, he still has his fair share of redeeming qualities (even with the Crocs!) and was the perfect complement to Tara.

Overall, I had fun reading this! The events of the story also lead up to a Valentine’s Day Gala, so its a great read with February fast approaching! So basically you’re going to want to check it out when it officially releases tomorrow!

Rating: 4/5

SPELLS FOR FORGETTING - Book Review!

Say hello to what was my very first read of 2023! I’d seen this book around quite a bit over the last few months, so it felt right that my library hold came in just in time so I could read this in the new year.

This book was a bit of a blend of different genres like mystery to romance to fairytale to magical realism. I really enjoyed the writing, particularly in regards to the descriptions of everything because it was so atmospheric and really made me feel like I was on the island of Saiorse with our characters.

Years ago, Emery’s best friend, Lily, was murdered and the person accused of it was the love of Emery’s life, August. Though August was found innocent of the crime, the community still thought differently, and August ending up leaving the island…only to return again now. And his presences has begun to resurface old wounds and grievances and has Emery trying to reconcile with what actually happened.

The mystery aspect was my favorite part of the book. I was super interested in trying to get to the bottom of what happened to Lily and the roles (if any) that both Emery and August played in it. It was very much a slow burn to get to the truth, but in some ways I did appreciate the build up and how suspicion was created amongst the characters before getting to that final reveal.

One of the things I did struggle with though was the romance between Emery and August. There were moments where they both came off a bit immature for their age and even though this was written as an adult fiction, it felt YA-like. Sure, there were scenes that were on the sweeter side and they were easier to connect with, but overall I had a difficult time with it.

I also did expect there to be more magical elements to the story, so was disappointed there wasn’t. I did enjoy the very little hints of magic that did appear in the story, just wished there was more of that.

Lastly, the ending wrapped up very nicely, but I also thought it was underwhelming and maybe the chaos lover inside me, wanted more drama!

In the end, I think my high expectations let me down a tad, but I did still enjoy and can see why others really love it!

Rating: 3/5

HERCULE POIROT’S CHRISTMAS - Book Club Review!

Yes, I am sharing a book review of a holiday-ish read in January… this was my book club’s December pick and we got a bit behind on meeting, but better late than never!

This was everyone’s first official Agatha Christie read and the Queen of Crime delivered leaving us all wanting to dive into more of her extensive catalog!

The story is essentially about the wealthy Lee family (and a few outsiders) who come together during Christmas at the request of the head of the family, Simeon Lee. There’s always been some tension amongst the four Lee brothers and they soon find out their father wants to change his will. Very shortly after, Simeon winds up dead and the infamous Hercule Poirot arrives on scene to find out who committed the murder. 

The first part of the book sets the scene and introduces us to all the key people and their backgrounds. Though a bit slower, it was still well done and we liked in particular how Christie wrote each of the brothers to have their own distinct voice and personalities so it was fairly easy to tell them apart.

As for the mystery itself, it was very engaging and everyone did enjoy how it was all structured. It was engaging to the point where you had your own detective hat on and were trying to piece it all together in wondering who did it and why. Even if there were scenes that seemed less “important”, we soon realized that everything does have a purpose and there was probably still some minor clue hidden somewhere not so obvious.

In the end, the final reveal (done in true Hercule Poirot fashion) was shocking to some while others had a bit of an inkling. Regardless, the events that led to the order and the manner in which it was executed was so intricate and clever! It made us all think back on the details interspersed throughout the story and suddenly its like everything clicked!

Overall, everyone enjoyed this and many drew comparisons to the movie, Knives Out, though of course people now know where the inspiration came from!

Everyone rated it 4/5, so I’d say it was a very solid read!

If you haven’t read this yet, I suggest adding it to your holiday TBR for next season!

THE DIAMOND EYE - Book review!

If Kate Quinn writes it, you bet I’m gonna read it!

As usual, the author takes real life heroines and their stories and turns them into something special. Stories
that provide knowledge, understanding, and appreciation for those who fought, perished, survived, and lived through WWII.

This follows Lyudmila “Mila” Pavlichenko— a female Russian sniper— as she fights on the frontlines of the Red Army and becomes known as Lady Death because of her (official) 309 kill count. You learn about Mila’s background and the reasons why and how she ended up in the middle of the war and defending her country.

There’s so much meaningful discussion of identity as Mila tends to compartmentalize her former historian/ mother self with the sniper the war has turned her into. I also appreciated the conversations on death and how Mila approaches it because she breaks that sniper stigma of being a cold blooded killer with no emotion.

Aside from Mila, there was other characters like Lena, Kostia, and Lyonya that acted as great counterparts. On the flip side there was also Alexei, Mila’s husband (only legally) and he was the WORST. But he made the perfect enemy and also helped showcase the sexism and how woman were treated then.

Yes, this story is heartbreaking. There were a few chapters where I had to put the book down because it was so sad. But it didn’t shy from the horrors of war and instead showed the struggles and resiliency.

I did find the second half of the book during Mila’s propaganda tour in America, to be slower. Another plot does develop and it all came crashing down in climatic fashion at the end. It was clever, though did seem a bit out there for compared to the rest of the story, but I later learned this aspect was created by the author to fill in gaps of Mila's history.

Lastly the blurb in the author’s note was so fun: It mentions how WWII was won with Soviet Blood, British Intelligence, and American Steel. Quinn’s previous novel, THE ROSE CODE, depicted British Intelligence. Now THE DIAMOND EYE is about Soviet Blood. I will be eager to see if she covers the third, but really I’ll just read whatever comes out next!

Rating: 4.5/5

BEGIN AGAIN - Book review!

If you’re looking for a cute YA coming of age/ romance to read as we head into February, check this one out!

This book follows Andie, a newly transferred freshman to the super competitive Blue Ridge State, which also happens to be her late mother’s alma mater. Andie is determined to make the absolute most out of her time at college, but as you might expect, things don’t exactly go as expected. First, there’s her boyfriend she surprised with her transfer only to realize their relationship might be more complicated than she imagined. Then there’s her RA Milo, her new friends, and then there’s the well known and legendary campus radio show which she somehow founds herself right in the midst of! Throw that all together, and you get a crazy ride.

I thought this book was just so much fun and did a great job of depicting a young woman going through her freshman year of college and the highs and lows of it. It shows the struggles Andie has trying to fit in and find her footing at school while also finding the balance of schoolwork and social life. Plus, I really enjoyed the radio show aspect and the importance of it to the story.

I also really enjoyed the characters themselves and the group of friends. Her roommate Shay in particular will probably be relatable to a lot because she’s an avid book reader who runs a bookstagram, but also kind doesn’t have life figured out which I think can speak to a lot of us! Milo too with his caffeine addiction was a fun and slightly complex character because he’s that guy that seems to have so many different layers to him, but really is just super supportive in caring in his own way. And the tension between him and Andie throughout the entirety of the story was so palpable!

Aside from that, there were other great themes especially when it came to family. AND in true Emma Lord fashion, there were a few different occasions where this book brought up some delectable sounding eats (particularly the bagels!) that will have you craving something sweet!

Rating: 4/5

MAAME - Book review!

“Maame (ma-meh) has many meanings in Twi but in my case, it means woman.”

What an incredible debut by Jessica George! I can see thing being one of those “must reads while in your 20s/30s”, but honestly I think it’s just a must read.

We follow Maddie— a 25 year old English born Ghanian— and her journey to finding her own way, identity, and even claiming her name. For the last few years, Maddie has been the primary caretaker for her father who suffers from Parkinson’s. Her brother never steps in to help, and her mother spends half her time in Ghana. Upon her mother’s latest return, Maddie decides to finally move out and start her own life.

I absolutely loved Maddie. She was just a lovable and relatable character trying to navigate the messiness of life. Maddie has taken on the responsibility of caring for her father while simultaneously clashing with the rest of her family because they don't understand the burden. It’s so raw and you can see how this has affected her and there were many times I wanted to hug her (particularly when dealing with her overbearing mother). Her voice felt so real and I also loved that she (like myself) also Googles everything! 😂

Aside from that Maddie also experiences the trials and tribulations of all kinds of relationships including work, friends, romantic, sexual, etc. There’s moments she’s happy and feels like a whole new person and then others where she gets completely burned and has to learn how to handle these different situations.

Grief and mental illness are two other topics that play a focal point in Maddie’s story and I really appreciated how the author depicted these hardships in such an authentic and vulnerable way.

Lastly, it made me sad to see just how often Maddie was faced with micro aggressions and racism in her day to day life and in almost every setting. But again I think the author did this very well in incorporating these issues to create very insightful dialogue and conversation.

Overall, I really enjoyed and would recommend (its a BOTM choice!) because I can only hope others will fall in love with Maddie as much as I did!

Rating: 5/5

STONE COLD FOX - Book review!

What a compulsive and addicting debut! If you enjoy stories about con artists, anti-heroes, the rich and powerful, manipulation, extreme cat and mouse mind games… then you’ll want to add this to your TBR!

This story follows Bea, a woman raised by her swindling mother who’s looking to escape her dark past by marrying Collin Case and joining his uber wealthy family. Bea’s ambition to claim what she wants and believes she deserves has her facing off against other members of the Case family as well as Collin’s best friend, Gale, in the biggest cat and mouse game where the stakes are high.

Bea is an extremely complex character. She is absolutely flawed and damaged because of the horrible things she dealt with when younger and because of her toxic mother. Present day Bea is our narrator and she does not come off as particularly likable. Sure she’s extremely confident in herself, but her words and actions also make her seem very vain, pretentious, and her ambition to manipulate anybody and situation to her desires. We do also get glimpses into her past and as the story progresses you see some cracks in her facade and really begin to understand what she’s after and why. Admittedly, I tend to struggle with unlikeable characters, however Bea was very well developed and the very definition of an anti-hero that you hate to love.

The book also dives into the society of old money/ the wealthiest families. There’s a theme of “protect your own” and shunning outsiders into this world. It really showcased how different and how these groups really do operate in their own little rich world.

As for the battle of wits, it was interesting seeing Bea and Gale go head to head trying to outsmart each other. Plus it was suspenseful wanting to know all the secrets these two were fighting to bury or reveal. And then on top of that there was a little twist at the end that brought things to a new level and was just like !!!

Though I can see this be a bit of a polarizing read, overall I thought it was clever  with lots of psychological elements to keep you invested!

Rating: 4/5

Thank you @berkleypub for the early digital copy! This is out 2/14/23!

THE REUNION - Book review!

Sometimes you just need a fun and lighthearted Hollywood-esque romance and this one totally fit that bill!

The story follows Liv, an actress who became infamous for her role on a popular teen sitcom that began twenty years ago. During the show’s six year run, Liv always had a close relationship with Ransom, the actor who played her character’s love interest. That is until the end where things went awry between the two. Now, fourteen years later, the cast is getting back together for a one episode reunion special causing the past to collide with the present as Liv and Ransom are forced to reckon with their history as they also both begin to wonder what new strides they can reach in their careers.

I’m admittedly not and never have been the biggest tv show watcher or into the celebrity/ gossip scene, BUT I do still enjoy reading books about it like this one! It did make me think of things like Full House & it’s fairly recent reboot, as well as the Friends reunion— and because of that it made me feel all types of nostalgia for those types of sitcoms (even if I only ever watched a handful!).

There was a best friends to lovers and a second chance romance in this love story and I genuinely did enjoy seeing how Liv and Ransom’s journey played out and there was definitely some tension and sweet moments sprinkled throughout! Aside from the romance aspect, I also liked just seeing the different types of relationships the characters had with other members of the cast or even with their team. It did feel like getting an inside glimpse into the life of a celebrity! (Though I know there’s still gotta be some suspension of belief!)

I also loved how the inclusion of news articles/ tabloids, blog posts, and other forms of media to really make this feel like you were actually seeing celebrity drama unfold. Though this book made me despise paparazzi and gossip even more than I may already have— it just goes to show how its so hard to escape that sort of stuff when you have such a high profile and everyone’s trying to dictate the narrative.

Overall it was fun!

Rating: 3.75/5

Thank you @atriabooks @bookclubfavorites for the gifted copy!

THE HOUSE IN THE PINES - Book review!

I was so excited and had high-ish expectations for this because the synopsis sounded promising and it was a Reese’s Book Club pick… but ultimately I don’t think the execution was all there and it ended up falling flat.

First, we have the unreliable narrator in Maya. This isn’t always my favorite trope because it’s so overused at this point, but sometimes if it’s tame enough it does’ bother me. Maya, however, felt like she was written to be in your face about it and her drug and alcohol abuse got really tiresome and repetitive. I completely understand her history and she was having withdrawals that was affecting her, but she just felt like a lot.

Then there was the way the story was split into two timelines. It never explicitly differentiated when it shifted from past to present (like with a chapter heading) and while I get it may have been a stylistic choice to draw parallels between the two times, it became confusing to recall where you were at. Plus the pacing felt off where some parts were very quick to get through and others seemed slower.

And then the ending! I personally was super underwhelmed because even thought it was pretty obvious early on what Frank was up to, the revelations still were not satisfying and it felt like nothing was really solved and all the questions I did have weren’t answered at all. I also thought and wished for more about the book/ story Maya’s father wrote and it seemed like the author intended for it to be a focal point to the story, but ultimately it didn’t add anything extra.

I will say that this book was very atmospheric which is something that I do always enjoy while reading! The psychological elements and the concepts in which this story brought up were fascinating and certainly made me think which I also liked. Maya’s background and Guatemalan heritage and the way she’s tried to stay connected with it was also something I appreciated, though again, I do wish there was a little more.

This was a quick read though and I did enjoy the psychological elements and thought that went into those parts!!

Rating: 2.5/5

REMARKABLY BRIGHT CREATURES - Book review!

I can finally say I've read this and I get the hype!

This story is split into three POVs. First there’s Tova-- her son's disappearance into the ocean 30 years ago remains a mystery. Now, in her 70s, she works the night shift at the local aquarium in Sowell Bay. There she befriends the aging Great Pacific octopus, Marcellus. Then there’s Cameron-- a man who grew up without any inkling of who his father was and who’s mother abandoned him as a child. After getting a lead on his father, Cameron finds himself in Sowell Bay. The last (and my fave) narrator is... Marcellus the octopus.

The beginning was a tiny bit slow and I was curious how the narratives would tie together. But I do think it ended up working well to establish the characters and set up the story because once it all started to blend, this book shined!

There’s also a lot of dramatic irony where the reader (much in part thanks to Marcellus) knows more than our characters. And because of that it sometimes has you going “oh come on!” and it may come off a tad frustrating. There were definitely moments I wanted to knock some sense into Cameron especially, but ultimately it’s a necessary journey the characters needed to make for themselves.

I also appreciated how much I learned about octopi and how intelligent they truly are. Marcellus was written in the best and most charming way to really encapsulate that. His chapters and dialogue were so clever and had me chuckling because he had such a fun perspective on situations! He’s definitely up there as being one of the most wholesome characters ever. (Along with Rocky 🤩)

This was just one of those feel-good reads that covers things such as grief, family, second chances, finding your path in life, etc. Plus it also made me think about topics like animal captivity and the ethics behind it.

Overall this was just very endearing filled with a little drama, a hint of suspense, but mostly carried a lot of heart and kindness within its pages. The ending was sweet and not over the top, but the perfect conclusion for this unique story and each character’s journey.

Rating: 4.5/5

BLACK CAKE - Book review!

Sometimes you just need a messy family drama and BLACK CAKE certainly fit that bill! After seeing great reviews of this book, I finally decided that it was about time to pick up my own copy!

This is a generational family saga with the story beginning in the present after Benny and Byron’s mother, Eleanor Bennett has passed. The siblings have had a fraught relationship since an incident eight years ago and one of Eleanor’s final wishes is for the two of them to listen to a recording she made explaining the family’s history and then share a piece of black cake— a traditional Jamaican delicacy— when the time is right.

The story is not told in a linear timeline and instead bounces back and forth between the present and different times in the past to align with Eleanor’s recording. The central story is about a girl named Covey, who grew up in the Caribbean islands and what became of her. I did find Covey’s story to be interesting, though heartbreaking at the same time.

As the story continues and you learn more about what happened to Covey, you start to understand more of the family dynamics of the Bennett family both in the past and present. You can also see how Eleanor’s tale of Covey affects both her children and provides them with a new perspective on their mother, culture, and upbringing.

I did admittedly have some trouble following along with the aforementioned non-linear style of writing. At times it jumped quite a bit where it felt a bit disjointed for my liking. Plus, there seemed to be a lot of different characters and side stories that were introduced and I found myself more compelled by certain plot lines than others. It all did come together and wrapped up nicely in the end though!

Lastly, I genuinely appreciated and enjoyed learning so much about life in the Carribean and just a lot of the history behind it because there was so much I didn’t know. I especially liked how the author used black cake as a centerpiece to the story to each generation brought up!

While I may not have loved this, I still think it was a great debut with excellent themes and I will be curious to see what the author releases next!

Rating: 3.5/5

THE WRITING RETREAT - Book review!

What a wild book— and shocking to think that this was a debut!

To start, this book included a fun premise: a group of young female writers are invited to an excusing writing retreat at famous author, Roza Vallo’s secluded mansion in upstate New York. Our MC, Alex, is one of these individuals and she is determined to write something great with the help of her most beloved author and finally become published. But things don’t seem to be as grand as she hoped for being that she’s stuck on the retreat with her ex best friend and on top of that, things begin to get strange.

While the first half of the book felt a bit slower, it did a good job of setting the foundation and building up a sense of unease and anticipation because you knew something was bound to happen and it was inevitable for the pin to finally drop. And once it did… it was explosive!

There were so many twists and turns that I truly had a hard time predicting where this story was headed. On top of that, you could never really trust any of the characters so it made everything even more tense and really gave off some of those locked room vibes. But don’t worry, the psychopaths eventually reveal themselves and their end game and oh boy does it get intense!

This book was also much more dark and disturbing than I anticipated where at times it felt very much horror like even with some gothic and paranormal feels to it. I can’t remember the last time I felt this creeped out by a book, but this one definitely did it for me at times!

Aside from the main overarching story in itself, there was also some interesting plot points that came up throughout the course of the story. Some were unexpected and it took a little bit to grow on me, but by the end I felt that it all made sense and helped add an extra layer to the story, specifically regarding self growth and discovery.

If you’re on the hunt for a chilling psychological thriller, don’t miss out on this one!

Rating: 4/5

Thanks so much @atriabooks for the gifted digital copy!

CHECK, PLEASE - Series review!

Happy Sunday! Last night was a HUGE day as a Sharks hockey fan as they retired the very first number in franchise history of a legendary Shark. And I definitely bawled my eyes out.

In honor of that, I figured today would be a great time to (finally) share some thoughts of the CHECK, PLEASE graphic novel series that I completed back in January! Because hockey plus the second one includes a few Sharks cameos!

This series follows Eric “Bitty”, a former figure skating champion, blogger, and baker, as he takes on the challenge of competing on his college’s hockey team. It covers all four years of his time on the team, the dynamics between the players, the life of a college athlete (the parties, the mental aspect, etc), and so much more.

I just adored this series for so many reasons! First, I loved so many of the characters and the relationships they had with each other. There’s Bitty and his wholesomeness, Shitty and his hilarity, Jack and his broodiness, and plenty of others who add so much character to the story. It depicted not only their competitive/ athletic side, but also showcased the “bro-y” side of hockey culture which is VERY much a thing, but I won’t delve into that.

Then there’s the romance aspect which was sweet and I loved how supportive all the teammates were of Bitty and Jack. Though they each faced their own struggles, their story made me smile and I loved rooting for them.

As for the panels themselves, I was super impressed with the details of the illustrations! The dialogue was so fun and made me laugh several time. Though, I will say there were some times where it was a bit hard to properly follow the panels, otherwise I thought it was all very well done!

Overall, it’s safe to say that I enjoyed this graphic novel series. It was so heartwarming, cute, and made me want all the baked goods! Plus I felt like I could read about this characters forever because they were such a fun group and I loved following their journey!

Series Rating: 4.5/5

ALL GOOD PEOPLE HERE - Book review!

I feel like this book has made its fair share of rounds on the internet ever since it’s release last year and it was one where I felt like I didn’t need to give into the temptation, but when I happened to see it stocked at my local library… I thought, why not? And so here we are!

The synopsis of this sounded interesting enough— a thriller/ suspense taking place in a small town where twenty years a go, a young girl was kidnapped and murdered, but the case went unsolved. Now, Margot has returned to her hometown to take care of her uncle (and only father figure she’s known) who is suffering from early onset dementia. Upon her return, another young girl is murdered and Margot uses her journalistic drive to try and figure out once and for all what happened twenty years ago and if what’s happening now is the same person.

The story is told in two timelines through two different POVs. There’s Krissy, the teenager we see turn into an adult who loses her daughter that fateful night in the past. And then of course we have Margot who is on the hunt for answers. While I found both timelines to be captivating enough to each hold my attention, I think my biggest gripe was with the characters themselves. I didn’t find them to be fleshed out and developed enough and honestly, I just didn’t really like them. Sure, they’re not the most black and white characters, but some of their actions rubbed me the wrong way.

While the book does have its twists in it, I didn’t find them to be the most shocking and it felt like a couple of the earlier hunches I may have had ended up being right. Plus there was one part of the plot line where it felt like everything was just so convenient and I wasn’t a fan of it. Also, I don’t mind ambiguous endings, but this one was just a bit too much for me and it literally just ended and had me going “really, that’s it?”

Overall, it was a quick and fast paced read and I think the author has a knack for writing a compelling story— even if it is eerily similar to real life cases. I just think I’ve read plenty of other books of this genre that were executed a bit better.

Rating: 3/5

LOVE IN THE TIME OF SERIAL KILLERS - Book review!

I’ve been intrigued by this book since it’s release late last summer. I mean come on, just take a look at the title— how fun is that for a contemporary romance?!

The story started out great and I was hooked by the premise and our MC, Phoebe’s, fascination for true crime and serial killers. Not only was the scene set for a love story, but you could absolutely tell that family and grief were also going to be a big part of the plot.

I genuinely enjoyed the first bit of the story where Phoebe has some off the wall encounters with her neighbor, Sam, that are strange enough that some part of her thinks he might be a serial killer. Eventually, she realizes that might not be the case and instead, he could actually be… a good guy. Their romance starts off feeling like a slow burn which I truly didn’t mind at all, because it was filled with sweet moments and some tension. But then as the story progresses and when they finally get together, that lust and spark faded for me and I just felt like I didn’t really care for the relationship anymore and in some ways, it felt stale.

The other theme of the story that I did appreciate was the relationship Phoebe had with her younger brother, Conner. Phoebe’s childhood and adolescence was marred by fighting parents who eventually split leaving each of the parents with a child. This in turn caused Phoebe to have an even more fractured relationship with her father and also grow apart from her brother. Now, her father’s recent death has resurfaced some feelings from the past and it was interesting to see her correlate her love for true crime with her upbringing. And as for Conner, it was nice to see the two siblings reconnect as adults and really establish t themselves as family.

Lastly, there were definitely a lot of pop and nostalgia-like references which made things fun and relatable! But at times was also a lot.

Overall it was a quirky yet fairly standard read and even thought I may not have loved it, I’m still glad I finally read it!

Rating: 3/5

WHAT HAVE WE DONE - Book review!

Let's just say this was not quite what I expected, but not necessarily in a bad way.

Firstly, the synopsis was a tiny bit misleading. Twenty five years ago, Jenna, Donnie, and Nico were friends at Savior House— a place for orphaned teens that held its own horrors. One night they do something terrible that has stuck with them since. Now in the present, they are about to be forced back together to reckon with the truth and confront the past.

Sounds interesting in theory, and while all that DID happen, it occurred in a way I wasn’t ready for. I expected a typical thriller with narratives woven together to tell the story and create suspense. Instead, this was an extremely action packed story filled with hits and assassins.

This book was very much action driven rather than plot or character. One thing kept happening after the other that it was like reading a Jason Bourne story. Because of that, I felt like the plot suffered and I did wish for more character development because in the end, I didn’t really care too much about anyone.

This book is also split into four POVs— the three aforementioned friends and one that appears about a third of the way in (which is an entirely different story on its own). I was most enamored by Jenna, even though so many elements of her background were far fetched. The other two, I could never find myself invested in. Aside from the switching POVs, there also were timeline jumps… right in the middle of the dang chapter or basically with no warning! So it got me very confused sometimes. Like I need a heading or at least a paragraph break.

The fourth POV was interesting, but not fully fleshed out enough for my liking. It just felt off and random and instead its like it was thrown in to create more action and an enemy. Side note: the amount of times a pipe weapon was mentioned got grating.

I will say the non-stop action and quick chapters, made this read quickly and I was captured enough to want to get to the end and figure out what happened and who betrayed who.

If assassin stories are your thing, then check it out! Out now!

Rating: 3/5

THE MEASURE - Book review!

The only reason this book was on my radar was because of bookstagram, because prior to seeing so many reviews on it, I knew NOTHING about it. I also happened to pick this up while in a bit of a reading rut and it worked out well for breaking me out of it!

It’s been a while since I’ve read a dystopian-like story, but I typically enjoy them, this one being no different. Essentially, everybody in the world wakes up one day and receives a box with their name on it and a string inside. The string is supposed to represent life expectancy. Those with short strings will be meeting their fate sooner while those with longer ones will go on to have a longer life. As you can imagine, if something like this were to happen the world and society might descend into chaos and lead to a whole new way of living.

The story follows along eight strangers and how they each handle the situation and the fate of their strings. I found the development and concept to be so unique and intriguing! Right from the beginning it made you question what YOU would do if this occurred and so much more. It made you really think about the value of life and made you look at things from different perspectives as we followed along each character and their decisions.

The discourse brought up around short vs long stringers was so interesting to follow and it did bring up a political aspect that played a role in how the story progressed. There were definitely moments where this book was super frustrating because of one particular character’s actions and views on certain matters. On the contrary, there were other moments that made me believe that humanity can prevail and emphasized that there are genuinely just GOOD people out there regardless of their circumstances or the scenarios they find themselves in.

While I did really enjoy this, it wasn’t quite a five star because I did feel that something was missing in the end for me, though I can’t quite place my finger on it.

If you're looking for a fairly quick yet super thought provoking read, I highly recommend! It was a debut too which makes me even more excited to see what this author has coming up next!

Rating: 4/5

ICEBREAKER - Book review!

I’m sure you may have seen this book on your feed… I know I have! I was lucky enough to receive a copy and was dying to know what the hype was about especially because it had hockey! And enemies to lovers!

Sadly, it ended up falling flat for so many different reasons.

First there's the length. Personally, I don’t like my romance books to be more than 400 pages. If it is, it’s got to really impress and be a great story! Unfortunately, this came in at 430. Paired with the fact I struggled with the writing, it felt even longer because I just couldn't get engaged and found it disjointed. On top of that, the plot point of Nate and Anastasia partnering as a skating duo didn't happen until 200+ pages in! And then there were only like three scenes!

That leads me into the plot of this book which wasn’t that existent? It just felt so repetitive: the'd party, hook up, have some drama, and repeat. Plus, I felt like a lot of the situations were a bit far fetched for college students. Although, it was mentioned how uber rich a few were so I guess it makes sense they’re able to throw massive ragers and go out to fancy restaurants like its normal? Anyway, there really wasn’t much hockey at all which made me sad. 

Another grievance I had was the characters, mainly Anastasia. I hated how she treated Nate, especially early on. She was so hot and cold for no reason other than it being like a game to her and it came off very immature. Plus she seemed so hypocritical with the things she’d express vs. how she’d act and it was tiresome.

I did appreciate how the author wasn’t afraid to add uncomfortable topics like mental health, eating disorders, consent, and more. However at the same time I felt like she was trying to include everything and it became too much. While I also enjoyed some of the team aspects, there were a ton of side characters and little plots so it became hard to track.

Lastly, this book was SPICY which I didn’t mind.. But also maybe just a tad too many scenes (I go back to my repetitive point).

Overall this was a huge miss and I didn’t even mention the epilogue! Oh well, on to the next!

Rating: 2/5

THE FOUR WINDS - Book club review!

This was a book on many people’s TBR so it only made sense to read it together as a book club choice!

The story starts by introducing our MC, Elsa, and immediately you understand she is the outcast of her family and very much looked down upon. At the age of 25, Elsa finds herself wanting to experience life and after a rendezvous with Rafe, she finds her life completely changed.

Fast forward a few years to the early 1930s and the rough Dust Bowl Era and Elsa is living on the Martinelli farm with her two young children and in a marriage that’s always had unrequited love.

One of our favorite things about the story was how much we learned about this time in American history and understanding the struggles. The writing and situations were very raw and didn’t shy away from the atrocities of the time. Reading about how insane and dangerous the dust storms were was so eye opening! And to think it was all less than 100 years ago and due to poor farming!

Eventually after Rafe abandons the family, Elsa and her children set off west to California in hopes of a better life and to escape the harsh environment of the Texas Panhandle. Their journey and subsequent time in California is no better and again, gaining insight to the tragedies that were so normal for that era was heartbreaking and it definitely provided lots of room for discussion.

While the story did move along at a slower pace, especially at the beginning, we all agreed that it was still an interesting story. As mentioned, it doesn’t sugar coat anything and was definitely a sad read with very few uplifting moments. It also made us question what we do if we were living back then and it gave us appreciation for how things have changed.

The ending was admittedly not everyone’s favorite because what happened, happened so quickly that the satisfying aspect of it never was able to sink in. And I would say maybe about half teared up.

Overall though, it was enjoyed by everyone and really did make for a great book club book because we talked about things like the American Dream, unions (and communism), sexism, motherhood, and so much more.

Group rating: 4/5

THE SOULMATE - Book review!

I can’t believe this was my first Sally Hepworth book! I love me a good thriller/ suspense, but just never got around to reading one of her backlist titles.

This book begins when a woman seems to have jumped to her own death at a known suicide spot (The Drop), that also happens to be in the backyard of Pippa and her family’s new coastal home. Pippa’s husband, Gabe, has successfully talked people off the edge prior to this incident, but was unable to do so this time around. At first it seems like an open and shut case, but soon Pippa learn’s that Gabe knew the woman and the dominoes begin to fall.

I definitely was expecting more of your typical fast paced thriller, and though it was a quick and bingeworthy read, it felt like it leaned a bit more towards a domestic drama rather than thriller. I can’t concisely explain what I mean by it, but it just didn’t feel as thrilling as it could’ve been. Nevertheless, the short chapters along with the dual timelines and POVs did keep my engaged because I was eager to find out how everything came together and what led to that moment at The Drop.

As for the characters, I didn’t find any of the four main individuals to be particularly likable, but they also weren’t terrible. I just felt like I couldn’t connect to any of them. But with that being said, they all had morally grey aspects to them. They may have done some terrible things, yet in some ways you could understand why they did them.

This story also touches quite a bit on mental illness and how it can creep up on you, but also what it’s like to live with someone with a diagnosis and how it affects relationships and families. It was interesting and brought up some thoughtful topics, but there were some moments where it felt like it was just.. a lot.

Anyway, I did speed through this one and it was fine! There was nothing super special about it, but I did like how it kept me guessing and there was one little twist at the end. Overall, a good read and I’m curious now to check out Sally Hepworth’s previous books.

Rating: 3.5/5

THE HOUSEMAID - Book review!

A hyped up thriller that I was SO curious to read because of the reviews on it! I had this on hold at my library for a bit and was stoked when it finally came in that I had to jump right in… and I’m pleased that for the most part, this one actually lived up to some of its hype!

I will preface by saying the story and its plot felt fairly reminiscent to some other books I’ve read, one in particular (no title because spoilers!). But despite that, I still found this enjoyable and very entertaining. A popcorn thriller at its finest!

The book is split into three parts and the first introduces us to Millie. One of our MC’s who recently was released from a 10 year jail sentence and has found work as a live-in maid with the wealthy Winchester family. At first everything seems to good to be true, but after only being around a very short time, the matriarch of the house, Nina, begins to treat Millie terribly and her moods seemingly shift all the time. With no choice but to stick around, Millie puts up with Nina while also finding some solidarity with her husband, Andrew. 

While I don’t want to say too much about what else occurs, I will say that the author did an excellent job at painting the picture of the perfect enemy in Nina. She was quite cruel in her treatment of Millie and it took me some time to wrap my head around it. As the story progressed though, more pieces of Nina’s past came to light and you began to understand.

Aside from the apparent battle between Nina and Millie, there’s also another plot line that shows itself roughly midway through the book. This was definitely the twist that was meant to shock everyone and while I wasn’t totally surprised, I was still very intrigued to continue reading and get the full scope of things. And oh man some of the stuff that occurred from that point seemed so sadistic, but like I couldn’t stop reading!

The ending was satisfying, yet ambiguous enough for the sequel which released fairly recently! I am pretty curious about it so will probably end up reading it eventually.

Rating: 4/5

MEET ME AT THE LAKE - Book review!

This sophomore book from the author of EVERY SUMMER AFTER has the makings of being another big hit… but I feel like my thoughts will be on the unpopular side 🫣

I’ll start with some of the things that I enjoyed, the first being the atmosphere and setting! It takes place in Ontario and you get a wonderful mix of being the lake (Muskoka) and city (Toronto). And as someone who loves lots of things Canada— I adored this! I also liked the themes such as grief/ loss, finding yourself, happiness, etc and thought these moments were well written and honest. Also, really appreciated a lot of the secondary characters!

So what didn’t I like? Sadly, it was the romance piece itself which being a romance book… is a lot. The story switches between present and flashbacks and you learn that at the age of 22, Fern and Will spent one day together and then never spoke again. In the ten years since, there was a broken promise, but otherwise zero communication. When Will crashes back into Fern’s life they get their second-chance, but I had difficulty really connecting and rooting for a them because I had a hard time buying into the fact these two could suddenly pick up where they left off and be in love. Also the development wasn't quite there for me. Unfortunately the fated-lovers & insta-love trope has never been for me, but its great if it works for others!

I also was never a huge fan of Fern. Some of her behavior and actions, particularly later in the story didn’t bode well with me and its almost like she came off a bit pretentious.

Lastly, without going on a long spiel, I wanted to mention this story has a lot of emotional cheating and is fairly prevalent in Fern and Will’s backstory. While I understand this may be much more common and “innocent” than the physical kind, something about it felt icky to me particularly because of some of the criticism ESA received. I personally didn’t think the story needed it to help move it along and would've been fine without it. But that's me.

While I didn’t end up loving this, I’m positive plenty will and find it perfect for the summer season!

Rating: 2.5/5

THE PERFECT MARRIAGE - Book club review!

For our most recent book club pick, we decided to go with a domestic thriller— and after seeing this book ALL over recently, we chose to see what it was all about. I mean, a mistress, a murder, and a court case? Sounds super intriguing! Unfortunately, the hype for this one seemed to fall short for most. 

To start with the positives— this book read super quickly! There were quick chapters with alternating POVs (and occasionally alternating timelines) and this made for an engaging read because it left most people wanting to find out what the heck happened and who truly was guilty. Plus the legal side of things (while maybe some inaccuracies) was fun too.

However, despite the quick pacing there were still a few things that felt very off about this book. One was some of the inconsistencies and plot holes. There were a few situations and issues that were presented that either didn’t make a ton of sense, or were never circled back to later on.

Another thing (and this was one of my own big issues) was the narrative itself. Both POVs were told in first person perspective which was fine, until you get to the ending twist. Because This book felt like it was trying to mimic another VERY popular read, but the execution just wasn’t quite there because when you actually sit back and think about it, the narrative doesn’t make sense. But maybe that was just me.

Another thing a lot of us struggled with were the characters themselves, one in particular, because their actions were just so incredibly dumb it had us eye rolling at times. You also have to really suspend disbelief with some of the situations that occur throughout the story.

Overall, this wasn’t a favorite, BUT we did agree that it was still intriguing and twisty enough to hold our attention. And while it’s no masterpiece by any means, it could still be a good book to break you out of a reading slump if you just need something entertaining!

Group rating: 2.5-3/5
