YOURS TRULY - Book review!

The latest story from one of my favorite romance authors is here and all I can say is that this book was pure Abby Jimenez at her finest!

Abby has written some of my absolute favorite book boyfriends in the last few years and Jacob is right up there with the best of them!

This is a companion novel to PART OF YOUR WORLD (yes there’s Alexis and Daniel appearances) and centers around Briana, a dedicated and passionate ER doctor, and Jacob— a newer ER doctor in Briana’s hospital. The two don’t get off on the right foot, but eventually the ice breaks through some shared moments, vulnerabilities, and letters and what comes is a sweet and feel-good romance!

There was so much to adore about this book. But number one on the list is Jacob. You learn very early on that he suffers from social anxiety and I truly appreciated how Abby wrote his character with this. Jacob was just so honest and pure with the best intentions, but he also felt so REAL because of his anxiety and the way he coped and handled it. Briana on the other hand took a little bit to warm up too, but once I did she stood out in her own, flawed way.

While the characters were a huge reason I loved this, there was still the story itself I enjoyed. It included fake-dating, a dog, and letter exchanges for an epistolary element! As you can expect from this author, the story wasn’t all just warm and fluffy but delved into some more serious topics such as the aforementioned anxiety, loving yourself, chronic disease, new beginnings, and so much more to make for a powerful read.

The one thing that held it back from being five stars was some of the miscommunication and Briana’s later actions. The miscommunication did make sense for this narrative in some regard, but at one point it felt like just a tad too much. And then for Briana, she made some rash choices which I had a hard time with, but I guess it made sense for her character development. And I am glad her issues were addressed in a healthy way.

Overall, if you’re an Abby fan, get excited for this one!

Rating: 4.5/5

Thanks @readforeverpub for the gifted digital copy!

IN THE LIVES OF PUPPETS – Book review!

If you’re a TJ Klune fan and have enjoyed his past works as much as I have, then get ready because you are in for a treat with his latest!

This story includes machines vs. humans, found family, love & sexuality, adventure, freedom of choice, BEING BRAVE, and so much more. Also, at different times and for different reasons, it totally gave me Westworld, Tarzan, Star Wars, and Avatar vibes.

Anyway, the premise is that Vic is a human who lives among machines: there’s his dad, Gio, the sociopathic (but still loveable in her own ways) Nurse Ratches, and the overeager vacuum, Rambo. They live in the forest and have created a nice quiet lifestyle. That is until Vic discovers the remnants of a machine in the scrap yard and decides to bring it back to life. Hap soon joins the family and is a complex machine with a brutal past he has no recollection of. However, Hap’s presence changes everything and Gio is taken from the forest revealing secrets of his own creation and leaving Vic and Co. to take off from the comfort of the only home they’ve known and go on a journey to rescue him.

I don’t even know where to begin with this. It was just so full of heart (pun intended) and hope and once the foundation of the story was set, I couldn’t put it down. The found family aspects were wonderful and I loved the relationships Vic, a human, had with the machines and vice versa. Plus it really made you questions things from a new perspective such as humanity, love, memory, and choice.

I also really enjoyed the humor in this one as well! It did include more crude/ sexual innuendos and jokes which may not always be for everyone, but it totally made sense why because this story touched on sexuality and how its not a one size fits all, but more of a spectrum.

While there’s so much more I could share about this story, I’ll end it by saying that this book is quite an adventure, but one that will stick with me for a bit. It’s full of heart and I felt like I was right there with Vic and everyone else throughout the journey and I can’t wait for others to be as well!

Rating: 5/5

What’s on your Sunday to-do (or to read) list?

HAPPY PLACE - Book review!

Tomorrow is the day— Emily Henry fans, rejoice! Because she is back with her next book and as expected, it was wonderful and heartwarming and everything you could imagine in and Emily Henry story.

The story follows our MC, Harriet, as she joins her two college best friends, their partners, and her ex-fiance (though none of the rest know this yet), for one last hurrah at the Maine cottage they spent so many summers at. During this stay, Harriet is forced to reckon with what happened to her relationship with Wyn and to truly think about what makes her happy in life. Not only does this include a love story with a second chance romance, but it’s also about friendship and the work it takes to maintain them as people begin to move into different phases of life.

For starters, I adored the setting of this one. It just gave off such cozy and nostalgic summer vibes + I loved how much friendship was a central theme to this setting, so much that it made me think about all the past and future trips I’ve shared with friends! (Ironically enough, I read while on one!)

I also just really appreciated seeing Harriet’s struggle to find happiness and understanding herself through such difficult times like a broken engagement or being dissatisfied with her career or the fact that her “happy place” of the cottage will be non existent soon. It felt very authentic as it was told in two timelines, the past and present, and you got to really understand everything Harriet and the friend group has experienced over the years and how the group dynamic is changing as they each begin to take big life steps such as marriage and children.

As for the romance piece, I did enjoy following Harriet and Wyn’s journey because it was messy and complicated and choices were made whether it was the right one or not. However, seeing them start to realize why the events of their past transpired felt enlightening and it made me happy even through the dark times.

Overall, I really liked this and I think any Emily Henry fan will well when it officially hits shelves TOMORROW!

Rating: 5/5

Thanks so much @berkleyromance for the gifted digital copy!

HOW I’LL KILL YOU - Book review!

Okay... identical triplet sisters who have a habit of alternating kills of their boyfriends, how could not that be interesting to a thriller lover?

The story is told through the POV of the youngest, Sissy. And no, that’s not her real name, but the triplets came up with names for each other because they didn’t like the ones the state had given them after they were found abandoned in a stroller as babies. Anyway, Sissy is the next sister in line to find a mark to make her boyfriend before killing him. And they’re able to get away wit it (like the previous six times) because nobody knows there's multiple of them.

But back to Sissy. She’s always been the “cleaner” of the family and has yet to kill. Meanwhile, her sisters are vastly different and seem to both enjoy the game for their own reasons. Sissy eventually chooses Edison as the man to make fall in love with her before she buries him. But as time ticks down to the inevitable kill, Sissy finds herself second guessing everything including her own sisters.

I will admit the pacing of the story felt a little off. The beginning was very intriguing because you quickly get an idea for each of the triplets’ personality and get glimpses into their dynamic and why they kill for and with each other. You also learn in pieces, their upbringing, how they were split up in different foster homes, and their different experiences within the system. However, I found the middle parts a bit slower. Here, Sissy gets to know Edison more and also begins to truly wonder about her own future and question things about her sisters. 

The ending both explosive and thought provoking. There’s some action that occurs and suspense around what choices Sissy and her sisters will make. In the end, you’re left pondering about identity, family and what it even means or where the line may be drawn when it comes to them. It wasn’t all wrapped up in a nice bow because and I really enjoyed that!

Overall, I had fun with this book and will be curious what the author writes next!

Rating: 3.5/5

Happy May & Happy AANHPI / Asian Heritage Month! During the month of May, a lot of countries have their own celebrations to recognize the influence, contributions, and achievements of Asians on the history and culture.

There are SO many incredible books by Asian authors that cover everything in the Asian diaspora— the ones I’ve showcased here are just a tiny glimpse of some great titles! Believe me I could’ve included way more, but had to limit myself!

I kicked off my reading month with WELL, THIS WAS UNEXPECTED by Jesse Q. Sutanto (a go-to own voices author for me!) and it’s so cute! Think Crazy Rich Asians, but YA and more angsty!

Do you have any favorite books by Asian authors or any favorite authors?

THE GOLDEN SPOON - Book review!

This book was so much fun! Imagine The Great British Bake Off, but then add in a little bit of a murder mystery element and you have this debut book by Jesse Maxwell!

The story follows along six home bakers as they arrive at Grafton Manor, the home of America’s Grandmother, Betsy Martin, and the location of the show, Bake Week. Over the course of the next week, the contestants will be pitted against each other in a series of bakes with one person being eliminated each day until one is left and wins the coveted Golden Spoon. But off the bat, things start to wrong and a sinister undertone begins to take shape…

This book is told in seven POVs— the six bakers and then Betsy herself! Though it took a tiny bit of adjusting to catch onto the narrative shifts, I did like who each character had their own distinct personality and background that it made it easier to remember each AND figure out who your favorite characters were.

Throughout the course of the competition, I genuinely felt like I was watching a baking show, but in book form and I loved it! Plus it made me crave so many baked items so prepare yourself! Aside from the “on screen” aspect, I also enjoyed the behind the scenes where you start to learn that something is going on at Grafton Manor. Certain contestants are seemingly being messed with during their bakes and you don’t know why are who. But the conspiracies behind it are endless.

Ultimately, everything comes crashing down at the end and secrets come out for the first time in decades. Admittedly, my biggest critique of this book was with the ending because it felt very rushed when I didn’t think it needed to be. (The book is only 270 pages so could’ve been drawn out a bit more.) Plus I thought the reveal into the whole baking mess was so quick and underwhelming that it left some to be desired.

I still very much enjoyed this and found it to be a fun mystery! It did also cover some other topics like workplace assault/ abuse, depression, and more + had a sweet found family aspect to it in the end.

Rating: 3.5/5

Thanks @atriabooks @bookclubfavorites for the gifted copy!

EVERYONE IN MY FAMILY HAS KILLED SOMEONE - Book review!

This book was only of my latest #bookstagrammademedoit reads and I have so many thoughts on it!

This is a murder mystery with a fun and unique on it, mainly because of the narrative and the way it was written. Plus it plays homage and is very reminiscent of some classic detective novels by the likes of Agatha Christie and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.

The set up was interesting, right from the get you could tell it was going to be a fun to learn about what happened on this family reunion and how each family member has each been involved with well… killing someone. 

The story was broken up into different sections with each one being about a specific family member and a little more about their backstory. I thought this structure was fun and helped build quite a bit of suspense and an aura of guilt around so many people because in their own way, everybody was a little off and had their own issues they were trying to deal with. Safe to say the family drama was plentiful with this one!

One of my favorite parts about this book really was the voice of the narrator, Ernest. The premise is that he’s writing a book and the story about what happened so his narration is speaking AT the reader which I found entertaining. Plus it was written in such a clever way with little easter eggs and foreshadowing. However despite that, I did find myself surprised by a few of the twists in it.

I think the part I struggled with most was honestly just understanding the complexity of all the crimes, the history of the Cunningham family, and how each individual played a role in that to tie it all together. I personally found it a bit confusing to follow along the web of details to fully grasp the how and why because I think the was just so much to it. Also, when the revelation is done (in a very Poirot kind of style), while there was a lot of facts being explained it also felt like an info dumping.

Overall though, I still enjoyed it for the most part. The ending and one character’s fate in particular was pretty fascinating once you understood their psyche because it definitely gave me something to think about!

Rating: 3/5

WELL, THAT WAS UNEXPECTED – Book review!

My first read of May and I had a blast with it! Think Crazy Rich Asians, but make it YA and more angsty and very sex positive and that’s what you get here!

This story follows Sharlot (Jesse Q. Sutanto’s jokes about name misspellings in Asian cultures will never not give me a laugh) a very typical 17 year old who gets caught in an unfortunate incident with her boyfirned. She then finds herself whisked away to Jarkarta, the place her mother grew up and left 17 years ago. We also have George Clooney, of the uber rich Tanuwijaya clan. George is involved in his own mishap which causes his father and younger sister to intervene in finding him a “real” girlfriend. The results? Catfishing, fake dating, real feelings, overbearing family, lots of food, drinks, and plenty of laughs.

There was so much I adored! First being how much I learned about Indo-Chinese heritage and Indonesia itself. It made me really to visit Jakarta and Bali after all the talks of the sites and delicious eats!. It was also interesting how it juxtaposed Sharlot, and American born Indo-Chinese, to those who are native to Indonesia and how their upbringings and mindsets are just so vastly different because of the cultures.

Sharlot herself was also an intriguing character. She came off pretty harsh at times, especially towards her mother, but I enjoyed seeing her growth as she began to understand more about her mother, her own heritage, and the reasonings behind why her mother kept so much of her past a secret from Sharlot.

This book was also just fun and hilarious! I love fake dating and seeing Sharlot and George start off on the wrong foot and grow to eventually have feelings for one another was a chaotic, but sweet journey.

I also just appreciated how this YA dug into some deeper topics like slut shaming and LGBTQ+ views particularly in a conservative country. While sad and frustrating to read at times it shed light on just how different other places in the world are from what we may be familiar with.

Overall, this was a lovely read and this author as absolutely an auto-buy for me now!

Rating: 4/5

IN THE WEEDS - Book review!

This is my second BK Borison as I did read LOVELIGHT FARMS over the holidays and while I thought it was cute, I admittedly didn’t LOVE like so many people have. But I did really enjoy the small town vibes and characters, so I was still super excited to read Beckett and Evie’s story!

Like with the last book, I adored the whole small town setting of Inglewood. It seems like such a wonderful and cozy place + I loved how tight knit everybody was in that typical small town way. I mean the gossip and phone tree is just great! Plus it was awesome seeing more Stella and Luka and then getting more of Layla and Caleb (who I know is the next book!).

I also enjoyed how it didn’t shy away from making Beckett— who on appearances and first take comes off as this hulking, tatted, farmer— but is really a bit vulnerable with his social anxiety and sensory issues. I enjoyed learning about his background particularly with his family. As for Evie, I appreciated her self reflection arc on stepping away from her social media livelihood to instead try and figure out what truly makes her happy. Sure, it came off as a bit cliche at times, but overall was nice.

What I wasn’t that big a fan of was parts of the romance story between Beckett and Evie itself. It started off with a weekend fling as strangers, but that weekend led to months of pining which I had a bit of hard time with because the trope has always been hit or miss for me. As the story progressed and they got reacquainted I think I just struggled to really find and understand the chemistry between the two. And while the miscommunication trope was to be expected, the one on this story just felt a little too much for my liking.

Also, while the author definitely knows how to create wonderful characters and dreamy settings, there were parts of the writing that felt a bit too repetitive.

Anyway… I’m still very much invested into this series and town and will eventually read Layla and Caleb’s story!

Rating: 3.5/5

ADELAIDE - Book review!

I went into this book without a lot of expectations and I'm so happy I did because I loved it and it will go down as a 2023 favorite!

Don't be fooled by the gorgeous cover and go in thinking this is happy and fun. The story follows Adelaide, an American in her mid twenties living in London. She's finishing up her masters and working when she meets Rory Hughes, her Disney Prince, and get wrapped in his enigma which leads her down a self destructing path and ultimately to an unwell mental state.

So much of Adelaide’s relationship with Rory felt so relatable which is why this book hit so hard. If you’ve ever been in a relation/situationship where you’re putting in 110% and the other is only putting in maybe half that, you get Adelaide and Rory. If you’ve ever felt yourself get so invested in someone because they’re the one you’ve always fantasized about, Adelaide will resonate with you. Immediately you can tell Rory is no good for Adelaide, but she’s so fixated (almost obsessed) that he’s The One, that she ignores all the red flags that are obvious to others.

As an outsider's perspective, it may be easy to recognize that kind of behavior, but when you’re in it, it’s an entirely different story. Particularly after Rory experiences a tragedy, Adelaide finds herself wanting to be supportive for Rory because she’s the type who wants to help and will put others before herself. Even when Rory is unappreciative of her, she justifies his behavior and believes SHE’S in the wrong.

Adelaide has trauma from her past that contributes to her sense of self worth as she spirals. It’s so easy to compare yourself to others, especially ex’s or the future partner, of someone you dated. And that is something Adelaide continued to do until she hit a breaking point which I’m sure happens a lot more in the real world than is talked about.

The mental health discussion in this book felt so honest and raw because Adelaide’s story is one many will be able to relate with. Plus the story still ended on a positive/ hopeful note and I loved the support Adelaide always had when it came to her friends!

Rating: 5/5

Thank you @stmartinspress for the gifted copy!

ALL MY RAGE - Book review!

I knew this book was going to be incredible and powerful, but it still did not prepare me for just how devastatingly beautiful it would be.

This story primarily follows two teenagers of Pakistani heritage and their lives growing up in Juniper, CA. Salahudin and Noor were best friends because they were both outcasts who understood each other when nobody else could or wanted to. Eventually The Fight caused a riff, but new circumstances have caused them to be drawn towards each other again as they’re each faced with unthinkable obstacles.

I had such visceral reactions throughout the course of this read because of the content and comprehending the reality of the situations. Sal and Noor’s stories were gripping, yet heartbreaking and it felt so raw. I had a ton of rage reading, particularly when it came to the blatant racism and abuse they constantly experienced. It’s horrifying how much people love to hate and hurt on others.

This book also did a great job highlighting the immigrant experience and the work put in to live the American Dream. There are chapters from Sal’s mother, Misbah, sprinkled in and you get an understanding for her past and how she carries so much hope with her. The dream and strive to keep things going is passed along to Sal who views things with a different eye, but knows he can’t let his mother down so he gets caught up in things he shouldn’t and even unintentionally drags Noor into it.

The events in the final third of the story created such a mixture of emotions that it felt there were no right answers to how everything would conclude. I had many conflicting feelings that left me deep in thought as it all unfolded. I can’t necessarily say it was a happy ending, but it was a hopeful one that will give you a lot to think about.

While this book is heavy with its content and social issues, it is a very important read and I would recommend it to anyone. The writing and storytelling is well done and I felt like I learned so much of Pakistani culture. This is a story that will be sticking with me for a while!

Rating: 5/5

THE LONDON SÉANCE SOCIETY – Book club review!

The last read for my IRL book club was this magical realism/ historical fiction! While the picnic vibes for our meeting were immaculate (we love you @traderjoes ), unfortunately the book was not quite as special as we had all hoped it would be.

The story follows Lenna Wickes as she becomes an apprentice to Vaudeline D’Alliere, a spiritualist well known for being able to summon the dead and get answers and closure from them. Lenna is determined to learn about what happened to her sister Evie who died mysteriously. Then there’s the London Séance Society—a male’s only club that performs seances, but it seems like they are up to some trickery and also maybe some corruption…

Starting with the good! It was interesting to learn more about that time period in the 1800s of Victorian London because society was of course, so different than what we all know of today. Plus it was fascinating to learn more about seances and how they seemed to be much more common back in those days. We did also enjoy how it was written from two different POVs, including one in the first and one in third. The mystery surrounding Evie’s death and her prior whereabouts were also was intriguing enough to keep everyone guessing on what exactly was occurring.

However, there were aspects of the story that weren’t as strong. Firstly, it felt like the plot moved fairly slow and a lot of us had a hard time really feeling engaged by the story and its characters. Also, none of the characters stood out in any way and were kind of just…blah. Even though the book had some otherworldly elements, there were moments and situations where it felt like you had to suspend disbelief still.

Some of the writing itself was also a bit of a miss for us because it felt like it was trying too hard and it came off as being a bit repetitive.

While the ending was definitely very fast paced and a lot was revealed, ultimately it wasn’t enough to really change anyone’s mind about this book just being fine. Overall it was a book we read, enjoyed discussing, but it really wasn’t that memorable. Well aside from the usage of the word “omnibus”.

Group Rating: 3/5

ROMANTIC COMEDY - Book review!

This was my very first Curtis Sittenfeld book, and I’m sad I didn’t love it more. I’m not sure if it was just this book or the author, but here are some thoughts on of the most buzz worthy books of late!

The story follows a comedy sketch writer, Sally, and the workings of the live late night comedy show she works on which is basically SNL. During the week Noah Brewster, a famous pop singer, hosts Sally finds her and Noah instantly connecting in a way she didn’t think possible. Because Sally has been around enough to see how several ordinary guys on the show seem to hit it off and find love with glamorous women. But she knows that could never happen if the roles were reversed.

The book is split into three chapters. Yes, three. The first I did find interesting to start because it dove deep into the inner workings of a show like SNL. It walked you through what an average week looked like for a sketch writer, the late nights, and all the work put in. While I enjoyed this at first, it became monotonous when it was 100 pages long. Also in this section, you see the first bits of Sally and Noah’s relationship and honestly? I never felt it. Plus I wasn’t a huge fan of Sally’s constant “woe is me” attitude.

The next chapter is a hundreds pages with of email exchanges between Sally and Noah during the pandemic lockdown. Here, you see them begin to open up a bit more with each other which was nice. While I enjoyed this section better, I still struggled to connect with them and the story.

The last chapter is when Sally decides to spend quarantine with Noah and their relationship takes the next steps because they actually get to do things in person and private! I still never felt invested into them and Sally was still so hell bent about the whole “a guy like him would never be into someone like me” that it became so grating.

I do typically enjoy a good celebrity romance story, but aybe it was the drawn out chapters, or just the writing, I’m not sure. One day I’ll give the author another try, but unfortunately this one wasn’t for me even though it’s been loved by so many others!

Rating: 2.5/5

MINI REVIEWS!

I have a few books I’ve read recently-ish where I didn’t have the brain capacity to write a full review. So instead, here are a few thoughts on these four books!

WHAT THE NEIGHBORS SAW: A fresh voice in the thriller! Elite DC neighborhood with some real housewife vibes and a murder… super quick read and very bingeworthy. Enjoyed the commentary on class, race, etc. and was entranced by the lives of the elite and those who aspired to be elite. A little underwhelming end and also took a turn I wasn’t expecting and am still unsure of how I liked the twist.
Rating: 3.5/5 (out 6/20, thank you @minotaur_books !)

MY MECHANICAL ROMANCE: Such a fun and cute YA romance focusing on STEM, specifically women in STEM! Learned more than expected (and was fascinated) by robotics. Appreciated the conversations of the struggles young women face stepping into this field. Some of the science-y talk went over my head, but it was fine! Wasn’t a huge fan of the MMC, but still enjoyed overall.
Rating: 3.5/5

HOLDING PATTERN: Loved the immigration and Chinese culture rep. Very interesting albeit a bit weird of a premise, but had heart and discussed the intricacies of mother-daughter relationships. Some quirky characters and situations and at times I didn’t feel connected to the story. Overall though, a short read with some thoughtful themes.
Rating: 3/5 (out 6/20, thank you @riverheadbooks !)

THE GIRLS OF SUMMER: The Greek island setting was dreamy! The rest of the book was not quite for me. Yes it’s a thriller and had some disturbing topics brought up, but written in a way that I wasn’t a fan of. I know I should’ve felt sympathy for the MC, but I struggled to because there wasn’t enough character development or explanation to why she behaved the way she did. Very quick read that held my attention enough, although was also fairly predictable.
Rating: 2.5/5 (out 6/6, thank you @stmartinspress !)

Off to finish up what will likely be my last read of May with A SCATTER OF LIGHT by Malinda Lo!

THE QUIET TENANT - Book review!

If you’re looking for a quick and bingeworthy thriller to this summer… add this to your shelf!

This is a chilling thriller that involves a serial killer, named Aidan and the three women in his life who are currently closest to him. There’s the woman (Rachel) who he kidnapped five years ago and instead of killing her, has kept her alive in a shed since. Now, sudden life changes have caused him to move her into his home where she now has (limited) access to another human: his 13 year old daughter, Cecilia. Then there’s the third, Emily, who works at the local restaurant and has her eyes on Aidan.

This book was addicting from the beginning! Told in alternating perspectives of the three, it did a great job of keeping me engaged and also wondering what was going to happen. Rachel’s narrative was the most interesting because of her harrowing story and the way Aidan has asserted his dominance and control over her during the five year span she’s been his victim. While infuriating to see how she was treated and victimized, her storyline also showed a lot of resiliency during her fight for survival.

It was also fascinating to see Aidan and Rachel play the part of domesticated roommates in front of Cecilia, but then learn what actually goes on behind the scenes.

I did have a few issues though, most of it having to do with the ending because ultimately I did find it to be fairly unsatisfying because a lot of the questions I had were not answered. They "why" of everything was never explained and I wish we had learned more about Aidan’s psyche to commit his crimes. There were a few super short chapters thrown in that were not from one of the three main POVs that were so interesting and I wish that angle had been explored more. I also thought there would be more drama or expanded relationships between Rachel, Emily, and Cecilia towards the end, but that also didn’t quite happen in a way I would have hoped for.

Overall though, it was still a fun and fast read that made me question things like whether I would ever have the smarts and instinct to survive like Rachel!

Rating: 3.5/5

Thank you @aaknopf for the gifted copy, this releases 6/20!

Boston bookstore photo dump 💛📚

Happy Friday, I’m back! I spent the last few days in Boston aka one of my favorite cities and had the best time. I hadn’t been out for a proper visit in a few years, but its a place that holds a special place in my heart and it felt so good to be back!

Not only did I get to visit SEVEN (7!!) bookstores, I got to indulge in some of my favorite foods (fried clams, lobster, JP Licks ice cream), get in lots of walking, and spend a ton of time with family making fun memories and learning new things like mahjong!

On the reading front, if you follow my stories, you probably saw that I was reading the highly anticipated and hyped up FOURTH WING! I finished it yesterday and I’ll just say I cannot wait for that second book to release in November! The question is… what to read now?

Catch me up on what you’ve been up to and reading!

YES, DADDY - Book review!

So I knew heading into this read that it was going to be a dark one, but even that forewarning did not adequately prepare me for how truly dark it was!

The first chapter of the book takes place at a trial where we learn a witness has been asked to testify at a rape trial. This witness makes a choice on the stand and then we are thrown back to two years prior where this whole saga begins.

Our MC, Jonah, is a struggling writer with a harsh upbringing and religious parents that put Jonah through conversion therapy because of the belief that would rid him of his homosexuality. The book is definitely tough at times, but that whole background is what helped shape Jonah into the man he is in the current day and how he makes his decisions. Soon, Jonah gets wrapped into the luxurious high life of a wealthy playwright, Richard, and his companions, but soon realizes everything isn’t as perfect as he hoped.

This is where the book gets dark as it begins to describe the toxicity of the relationship between Jonah and Richard, along with Richard’s other affluent friends and more vulnerable young men. It depict the imbalance and struggle between those with power and those who can be preyed upon.

There were several instances where my blood boiled because of the actions of these powerful men and the injustices occurring throughout, but I think that’s what made this book so good.

Overall, highly recommend if you’re into dark and disturbing thrillers!

Rating: 4/5

THE DAYDREAMS - Book review!

If you’re a fun of reunions, TV drama, celebrity romance, and just want to feel a little nostalgic, then check out Laura Hankin’s recent release!

This is about a popular teen show called The Daydreams. The cast was made up of four seemingly innocent teens who became close during their two seasons. But during their second season live finale, everything blew up and nobody spoke to each other again. Fast forward 13 years, they each have carried on with their lives in their own ways and have tried to put the show in the past. Now with the demands of a reunion special, they are forced back together to try and create some more magic, but old secrets may be revealed and it may just be a big disaster…

This book is told in two timelines, both primarily from the POV of Kat— the evil one on the show. While this book was entertaining and read quickly, it did feel more character driven than plot at times. I really enjoyed the dynamics between all the characters from both the past and how it evolved to present. Since they were just teenagers, it was messy and complicated, but also juicy because you kept wanting to know what happened during that finale!

I also really appreciated some of the other topics brought up such as misogyny in the workplace, specifically in the entertainment industry, by highlighting the bad behavior by show runners and other individuals in power. (I happened to read this on the heels of I’M GLAD MY MOM DIED and it paired perfectly.) It also brought up the issue of paparazzi/ tabloids and how a celebrity's every move is critiqued and one minor thing can be taken out of context and ruin perception.

While I enjoyed most things, I did wish for a bit more character development because there were times I felt like I struggled to connect with anybody or truly understand their behavior and actions.There was also the romance subplot that I just didn't feel invested in, maybe because of the characters itself.

This book has been likened too Daisy Jones and I can see how, but I do think this is its own unique story and if you enjoy this kind of thing, it could be for you!

Rating: 4/5

Thanks @berkleypub for the gifted copy!

LOVE, THEORETICALLY – Book review!

My third Ali Hazelwood book and I don't know how to feel anymore.

You hear about how her books follow the same formula and you want to believe it's not true... but it is. Big man/ tiny woman, enemies to lovers, the guy falls first, an evil enemy ready to take down the FMC because misogyny in STEM. I genuinely loved it the first time around in TLH, but at this point it’s just become predictable and repetitive.

For this book, I of course still really appreciate the women in STEM themes and how Hazelwood doesn’t shy away from shedding some ugly truths on what this field, primarily dominated by men, can be like. I also liked who our FMC in this story, Elsie, suffered from chronic illness (type 1 diabetes) and the struggles of that while not have adequate healthcare felt relatable.

This book does also have more of an academia/ politics within it feel which made it a tad different than some of her previous stories. I did also like a few of the side characters, such as George, and hope we can somehow see more of her someday.

Aside from the aforementioned grievances, another thing I wasn’t a huge fan of in this book was Elsie herself. She is and always has been a people pleaser which is something I totally understand, but there were parts about this that just felt off. It’s hard to explain, but part of it was how Jack came in, told her to say “honesty” and BAM it was like there was never an issue. Sure it can be seen as sweet, but I just had a hard time with her character.

Also, her obsession with cheese and Twilight was fun at first, but then I felt like it became a thing to constantly mention this and it became way too much.

While there were some qualities that made this book a little different, ultimately I found it too similar in structure and plot where I’m really wondering if AH can write anything else because I am tired of hearing the many adjectives to describe the big MMC. Like can we get something a little different?

Despite this, I can see myself still reading her books in the hopes of getting something new, but we shall see!

Rating: 2.5/5

Thanks @berkleyromance for the digital copy, out now.

HEARTSTOPPER SERIES 💖

I read these earlier this year and it was my first time diving into the world of graphic novels, and oh my goodness this series just made my heart burst with so much happiness!

I don’t think I have the proper words to adequately sum up how much I adored Charlie and Nick and the entire series. First we see their friendship grow into something more and it was particularly heartwarming seeing how sweet Nick was despite his internal confusion with his own sexuality. Their story also depicted the ugly side of things such as bullying, stereotypes, etc. and was so honest and genuine that it was easy to connect and root for the characters.

I also wasn’t prepared to get so emotional based off the sketches themselves, but Alice Oseman did a wonderful job of bringing the scenes to life that it made everything that much more special.

There’s not much else to say other than read this series if you haven’t already. You will fly through each novel and hopefully love Charlie and Nick as much as I did.

Now I need to go watch the Netflix series!

THE FOREBODING - Book review!

I was lucky enough to receive a copy of this debut (hand delivered from Colorado, by the author itself!) and loved how original it was!

The best way I could think to describe this would be: Blake Crouch + The Shadows by Alex North. This is a speculative fiction/ sci-fi thriller that broaches themes like control, manipulation, good vs. evil, and more while also discussing the strengths and power of the human mind and how remarkable, yet scary it can be.

One thing I immediately loved was how atmospheric it was. There were moments where I genuinely felt like I was there with our MC, Shiloh, while she experienced strange happenings around her. It was eerie and unsettling at times, but that’s what made it so intriguing. While it did take a few chapters to set the scene and get into the thick of it all, once a certain point hit it was hard to put down.

Some of the sci-fi elements that appeared were the ideas of psychokinesis & psychomanipulation— two concepts that while aren’t actually a thing (yet...), but made for some insightful commentary and thought. For example, what if you could will your mind to do cool things like move a book? Or on the darker side, what if people had the ability to access someone else’s subconscious and used this manipulation for their own good?

The plot itself was interesting as we followed Shiloh and her introduction to the world of psychokinesis and the realization that she herself is in the center of a lot of it. I enjoyed the other characters and the found family element there as this group of people worked together to stop the evil force of someone who seems to have gone rogue with their own agenda.

As for the science-y aspect of the writing, for the most part I found it easy to follow. Science was never a strong subject for myself, so it’s not unusual for some of the language in a sci-fi to go over my head, but I think the author did a nice job of making this story feel accessible for anyone to understand.

Overall it was an impressive debut and I would recommend if you like speculative thrillers and thought provoking reads!

Rating: 4.5/5

Officially releases 6/27, add to your TBRs today!

Happy Sunday!!

Every weekend I say that I need to finally take the time to sort and organize the stacks and stacks of books that are taking over, but every weekend comes and goes without me doing a thing and the stacks just keep growing. So I guess it’ll have to wait for yet another weekend… 🫠

In the meantime, just please enjoy these spines and the haphazardness of it all.

Spy anything here that catches your eye?

ONLY THE BEAUTIFUL - Book review!

My second book by Susan Meissner, but it’s safe to say that I’m a big fan!

This WWII era story, is like one I have never read before because it talks about the eugenics movement in the US and drew parallels to what was happening in Nazi Germany at the same time. You can imagine it made for an infuriating, but informative read.

The book is split into two halves. The first is from the POV of Rosie— a 17 year old with synesthesia. Rosie grew up on the Rosseau Vineyard in Sonoma, CA and remains there in ward of the vineyards’ owners, Celine and Truman until sent to what she believes is a home for unwed mothers.

The second half is from the POV of Truman's sister, Helen. She spent the last 40ish years in Europe as a nanny. During the war she witnessed unspeakable things that changed her. When Rosie was a child, Helen forged a friendship with her, so when Helen returns to California in 1947, she is determined to find out what happened to Rosie.

Both Rosie and Helen’s story was so heartbreaking because it really showed how cruel and mistreated people with disabilities were during that time. Rosie’s synesthesia as well as the deformities of a child Helen nannied for were both seen as a handicap and burden to society by their respective governments. And to make matters worse, these institutions took away people’s rights and made life altering decisions for them because they “knew better” and were “trying to only create perfect people”.

I just couldn’t believe the backwards thinking that took place in a time that really wasn’t that long ago. AND to learn that the ideologies that led to these atrocities occurring in America (and largely in California) are pretty similar to that of Nazi Germany was so eye opening.

The ending was also super powerful and as hopeful as you can be in a story with so many appalling events. The book also felt timely too because of the discussions it brought up around reproductive rights. And even as the author note stated, the eugenics movement may be in the past, but sadly the ideologies remain. And because of that, I found this book to be so so important and would highly recommend!

Rating: 5/5

THE SEVEN YEAR SLIP - Book review!

Ashley Poston has done it again! Like with her debut, THE DEAD ROMANTICS, I went into this book without a whole lot of background or expectations and I came out totally loving it! This sophomore book was utterly sweet and full of heart and character.

Clementine is struggling with the recent loss of her Aunt— the woman who very much acted like a mother figure and was her globetrotting partner ever since she was young. She’s been at the same overworked publishing job for the last seven years and overall is just sort of going through the motions of life. Clementine has also inherited her aunt’s apartment— a place that supposedly has a little magic to it. One day after entering, Clementine meets a man, Iwan, in the apartment and realizes that she has slipped back in time to seven years ago. What comes next is a story of timing and love and chances.

I’m a sucker for books with time travel, so go figure I really enjoyed the premise of this story! It felt original in its own way and I loved how the author structured these slips in time. Because even though technically, Clementine is meeting Iwan seven years in the past, it still felt like the present in some ways.

While parts of the romance plot felt fairly predictable, I still enjoyed following along and seeing how everything played out. I particularly loved the themes it brought up of chasing your dreams (or in the case of this story, the moon) and how those dreams and the person itself can change over time. It makes you want to reflect on self-growth and taking chances.

This was an overall clever and witty story with some scenes that will make your mouth water because of the delicious foods. It had its tender moments that were very heartwarming and I just loved its approach to the different relationships between the various characters. 

Rating: 4/5

JUNE READING WRAP UP 🍉☀️

I may be a few days late, but I finished up my June bujo! This was the time ever that I actually completed an entire month of journaling and I’m pretty proud of myself for that because when it comes to this hobby, consistency is not always my forte.

Reading wise, June was full of wonderful books across a variety of genres and I can’t wait to see what the next month brings!

Did you have any June book favorites?

VERA WONG’S UNSOLICITED ADVICE FOR MURDERERS - Book club review!

Had June book club last night, so it seems like now is a good time to finally share our May book pick.

The story follows Vera Wong, a widowed owner of a tea shop in San Francisco Chinatown. Business has been slow, she doesn’t have the closest relationship with her only son, Tilly (her motherly nagging seems to bother Tilly), and has a lonely routine she seems to stick to each day. However, things suddenly change once a body is discovered in her shop and she takes it upon herself to deduce what happened since the police aren’t taking the investigation seriously. What transpires are new friends, sneaky suspicions, a whole lot of laughs, and delicious food.

The most common words used to describe this book by the group would probably be adorable and heartwarming. Firstly, Vera is a force to be reckoned with, but such a great character. She embodied big grandma energy and was just a hoot! Some of us found ourselves doing things in our regular lives and wondering “what would Vera say if she knew I was doing this?”.

As for the mystery itself, it was done well enough to where it did have people guessing and wondering who committed the crime and how it was all going to play out. Although, some wished there for a bit more suspense throughout the entire story instead of just revealing a bulk of it towards the end. While mystery and detective work done by Vera was fun to follow along, like with a lot of cozy mysteries, it definitely had its far fetched moments and you have to suspend disbelief. But when you learned who the killer was, it all made so much sense!

One thing though that everyone loved about this book was the found family aspect. What was once a bunch of strangers at the story of this adventures turned into such a wonderful group of people— even when a handful may have been suspects. It was especially sweet seeing Vera have these people to dote on because she genuinely seemed like such a great and caring person, constantly spoiling everyone with delicious food!

Overall, this was an enjoyable read and if cozy mysteries are your thing, you’ll probably like this one!

Group rating: 3.75/5

COOL FOR THE SUMMER & GOING BICOASTAL - Mini reviews!

I have been really loving some YAs lately this summer and these two books by Dahlia Adler really encapsulated everything about why I adore this genre!

COOL FOR THE SUMMER: Such a fun coming of age/ identity story! I loved following Lara’s journey of self discovery because it came off so genuine and real. From her life-long crush on the star of the football team to feelings for the girl she met over the summer, I really enjoyed seeing Lara’s growth and becoming her true self. Sure there were some pain points that were to be expected for a YA, but overall it was quick, but wonderful read! Plus it totally gave me the good kind of high school nostalgia which made it fun! Rating: 3.5/5

GOING BICOASTAL: This one was an absolute blast of a queer YA rom com! It follows along teenager, Natalya’s summer, but there’s a slight twist: we get TWO different stories. One is of Natalya staying in New York with her father where she finally has the courage to talk to “the red head” aka Elly and start something new in the city. Then there’s the story of where Natalya instead chooses to head west to LA to spend the summer with her mother and work as an intern where she falls for the other intern, Adam, and finds a passion for other things. This book totally felt like a fun choose your own adventure type of story and both Elly and Adam were such great, yet different love interests and it was easy to root for both of their stories. I also loved how this wasn’t a love triangle and the ending will make you smile no matter what. It was another fast and addicting read that screamed summer! Rating: 4/5

If you have not read a Dahlia Adler book yet, I would recommend you do! Her stories are just so fun and well written and also have excellent Jewish rep and queer themes.

Thanks so much @wednesdaybooks for both of these gifted copies!

STRANGE SALLY DIAMOND – Book review!

If you're looking for a dark, compelling read this summer be sure to add this to your list!

This tells the story of Sally Diamond and her extremely unconventional and dark upbringing. After her father dies, Sally finds herself and her story propelled into the spotlight for reasons she was unaware of until now. What unfolds is the truth behind her shocking and vile past.

This story is told from two POVs. First, we get Sally herself who is in her 40s and seen as “quirky”. She might come off as neurodiverse, and while that may be part of the case, her social development was extremely different than that of typical individuals. And that’s mostly due to the childhood she has no recollection of. Then we get the narrative in the past from a boy named Peter who’s story was equally fascinating in its own twisted, psychological way. Told in alternating views, this book became so propulsive it was hard to put down even during the tough parts.

Sally comes off as naive, too literal, and awkward and while this may not be everyone’s cup of tea (think Nina from THE MAID), I really enjoyed her character’s growth and she was someone who was so easy to root for even through all the bad. Plus I appreciated how she wasn’t just quirky for the sake of it, but instead it was to show how a traumatic childhood could play a pivotal role in development. I loved seeing her learn social skills and have relationships with new friends and other family members. And even though she experienced lots of challenges, seeing her struggles made so much sense.

Now, Peter's character almost acted as a contrast to Sally’s which I found cleverly done because it made you think about how two people who both experienced trauma at a young and vulnerable age can grow up with completely different mindsets.

While the ending was a tiny bit underwhelming, I still flew through this one and think it was a super interesting read with some truly messed up family drama and dynamics. I cannot emphasize enough how dark it is, please check TWs!

Rating: 4/5

Thanks @bookclubfavorites for the gifted copy! Out 7/18

What did your weekend look like?

HELLO STRANGER – Book review!

When it comes to romances full of heart, Katherine Center is one of the bests!

The gist of the story is that Sadie takes after her late mother as a portrait artist, despite the arguments from her doctor of a father. After Sadie’s live is saved by a Good Samaritan, it is discovered that she needs (minor?) brain surgery to correct an issue. The surgery goes smoothly, but one of the results is that Sadie is temporarily suffers from prosopagnosia otherwise known as face blindness. Sadie is forced to adjust to this in the interim, but it’s not an easy task especially when she has other artistic goals and a couple of potential love interests…

There were so many reasons I enjoyed this, one of the main ones being the discussions it had surrounding facial recognition and the senses. It’s one of the those things we take fore granted, you don’t realize how critical that function is. It was fascinating to read more about the intricacies and how incredible  the human brain is that one misfiring can change so much. This book discussed confirmation bias and how we do it even if we don’t mean to, but that it can completely affect perception.

As for the romance, it felt slightly like a slow burn at the beginning only because it took longer than expected to get to our love interests. But once we got introduced, it was fun because Sadie’s inner voice was so fantastical and entertaining as she dreamt up different scenarios for each guy. Yes the romance piece was predictable, but I was still compelling because you’re left to figure out how everything ties in and is related to each other.

Another thing I liked about the story was how it addressed the miscommunication struggle in a realistic way since a lot people don’t tend to like this.

Aside from overcoming her face blindness, Sadie also learns how to stand up for herself when it comes to her family. Her father remarried shortly after her mother’s death, giving Sadie a stepmother and an EVIL stepsister. But in the end, it was nice to see her character growth and arc and how she used her mother’s influence into creating her own persona.

Rating: 4/5

Thanks @stmartinspress for the gifted copy!

If you’re on the hunt for a couple of solid summer mysteries/ thrillers, then I have two for you!

THE BLOCK PARTY: This book totally gave off some BIG LITTLE LIES x THE REAL HOUSEWIVES vibes and it was just pure entertainment from start to finish! There’s the wealthy/ prestigious neighborhood and its residents where they give off the impression everything is peachy when the reality is there are so many secrets. I loved how the story was told from two POVs— one from Alex, a mother in the neighborhood, and the second from her daughter, Lettie. There was so much drama when it came to both the adults and the teenagers so it was interesting to capture it from these two’s view. This book also had me guessing almost the entire time. You know from the start that someone has been killed at the annual block party in present time, but you don’t understand why without knowing what happened in the year leading up to it. And in that timeframe, there were SO many possible victims and suspects that I honestly didn’t have it figured out until right up to the moment it happened! Rating: 4/5

YOU CAN TRUST ME: I always enjoy a good con artist story and this one was quite entertaining and thrilling! I loved following both Summer and Leo and learning about their backstories that led them into the art of conning in the first place + they were both easy to root for. As for the central plot, it felt like a cat and mouse game between Summer and the uber rich business man/ philanthropist, Michael Forrester. The setting of the private island was fun and created a sense of mystery and I found myself curious as to where things were headed. While there were some surprises and twists, I also felt that some parts were predictable. Fortunately, that didn’t make anything less fascinating and I was hooked almost the entirety of the story. And the ending was filled with action! The conclusion leaves off a bit ambiguously and I still had some questions, yet it seems like there could be a follow up, but was satisfying enough. Appreciated the themes of class, vengeance, and sisterhood/ family! Rating: 4/5

Thanks @stmartinspress for the gifted copy of THE BLOCK PARTY! Both books are out now!

Happy Sunday! Sharing some of the fabulous book mail I have received over the last month plus because it’s been too long and there are just so many amazing titles here to choose from! I have my eye on several of these and cannot wait to get around to reading them soon.

In the meantime, the rest of my afternoon and weekend will be full of sun and relaxation! I started the THE HEIRESS last night which is the upcoming thriller by Rachel Hawkins, set to release in January— isn’t it wild that 2024 arcs and galleys are already here?!

See any books from this pile that catches your eye?

Thanks to the tagged pubs for the gifted copies!

DIVINE RIVALS – Book review!

A little while ago someone mentioned this book to me and it felt like ever since, I saw this book being talked about all over!

The concept of this story is quite unique as it two rivaling journalists begin to exchange letters through magic in their respective rooms. One of them is unaware they are speaking to their rival while the other does making for even more fun. Eventually the two find themselves reporting in the midst of a war between an awakened God who is seeking vengeance on a Goddess who ruined his life hundreds of years ago.

While on first glance and impression, this book gives off fantasy vibes, in all honesty, it didn’t quite feel that way. The world building was extremely simplistic (in a good way) and instead this story felt like a war era historical fiction with some magical realism elements taking place in a not too complicated world. And… I loved this blend of genres.

I found myself engaged throughout the story and wanting to know what was going to happen. There were moments that felt so intense that it was difficult to tear my attention from the page because I just needed to see how everything would end.

I also really liked the small bits of found family aspect and how people supported others in times of need. It also showed how some people are just genuinely GOOD humans who will go out of their way to help others even in the most dire of times.

As for the romance piece, I do enjoy a good enemies to lovers story and I really loved the inclusion of an epistolary format with the letters. Plus the communication between the two was so sweet and pure it became easy to root for them. And of course a little tension never hurt anybody! I do admit thought that there were a few things about the romance that came off a bit YA-ish for my liking, but overall was still nice.

The writing was another thing that was great with this story. It was beautifully written it was easy to get lost in this world and feel invested in all the happenings. The ending was also exciting and made the anticipation for the second book in this duology skyrocket!

Rating: 4.5/5

Thanks @wednesdaybooks for the gifted copy!

Do you ever come across a name in a book that has like… 🤨🙄?

Also this reel is just meant to poke fun at some of those ridiculous and cringey names, but is not necessarily indicative of how I perceived a book!

Are there other character names out there that had you going… why?!

NONE OF THIS IS TRUE - Book review!

Okay Lisa Jewell fans, buckle up because her latest is entertaining and a wild ride and I think it just might be her best yet!

This story follows the lives of two women who happen to live in the same town and cross paths on their shared birthday. The two are total opposites:— Josie and her life come off a bit strange, but that just could be due to her upbringing and the horrible events from her teenaged years that have led her to the present. Then there’s Alix, a podcaster with a caring (albeit unpredictable) husband, wonderful children, and the perfect home. The two forge an odd relationship of sorts when Josie asks Alix to interview her for her podcast to tell her story. Though there’s something unsettling about it all, Alix can’t help but be intrigued and carry on with the project, only inviting Josie closer into her life…

There is a ton to unpack with this story! Of course the plot itself was fascinating, although at times a bit dark. That didn’t stop me from reading and I found the pacing to be fantastic! As you read, only small hints and pieces are revealed at a time so I was constantly hooked and on edge waiting for more so I could put everything together.

I also really enjoyed the format and writing. There were lots of bits where it included a podcast or documentary transcript which also revealed more than what was already happening so you could prepare yourself for more. At time it felt like I was actually watching a true crime documentary unfold and I loved that!

As for the themes, there definitely are some darker undertones like grooming, pedophilia, abuse, and more. However, I think Jewell did an excellent job of weaving all this together in a way that made for a powerful story. The result was that the characters were complex and a bit morally grey so it made you question whether you should root for them or not in the end.

Overall this was a solid thriller with some interesting twists at the end to the point where I feel like I’m still digesting it all a few weeks later. This will likely go down as a top thriller of 2023 for me so don’t miss out!

Rating: 5/5

Thanks @atriabooks for the copy, out Tuesday 8/8!

✨ JULY READING WRAPUP ✨

July was a pretty decent reading month for myself— aside from one total dud, everything else was pretty solid, so overall I’m pleased with how the month turned out!

Did you have any memorable reads, good or bad, from July?

YELLOWFACE - Book club review!

What a smart and unique read! While this satirical story can be polarizing, it still was perfect for book club because it created some invigorating discussion!

This book is one that has certainly been talked about since its release and with good reason. The plot is simple: Struggling author June Hayward, a white woman, accidentally witnesses the fluke-y death of her frenemy, Athena Liu and in the aftermath, June steals Athena’s unpublished and unknown manuscript. Athena is a literary darling and June’s own jealousy and need for fame justifies her passing along Athena’s manuscript as her own. Thus ensues SO. MUCH. DRAMA.

Firstly, it was such a bold choice for RFK to write this story from June’s POV because June is probably one of the most despicable characters ever. She makes bad choice after bad choice and continues to dig her own grave, yet she completely thinks she’s in the right the entire time. It was like watching a train wreck yet you could not look away because it was still so compelling to follow. And it would’ve been so easy for June to avoid this mess in the first place if she was smart with her choices!

There was also the intricacies of the publishing industry that was brought up in this story which everyone found fascinating to learn more about. This brought up more great questions and discourse, one of the big ones of course being: who is allowed to write which stories? But then learning more about publishing made us really think about other topics like capitalism that really dictates a LOT and could be more of the issue.

While there are parts that felt a bit more unbelievable than others and the ending maybe wrapped up a bit too quickly and came out of left field, overall it was a story that left everyone with a lot to think about. Plus it just felt SO meta, especially with all the Book Twitter and Goodreads references!

Also, it’s worth noting that half the group listened to the audio while half read and it seems like those that read enjoyed it much more! To change things up, I’m including individual ratings below!

Me: 📖 4.5/5
KLS: 📖 3.5/5
RLE: 🎧 3/5
GG: 🎧 3/5
BH: 🎧 3/5
KM: 📖 4/5
AG: 📖 3.5/5
KB: 🎧 3/5

THE WHISPERS - Book review!

Ashley Audrain’s sophomore novel definitely has established her as a unique writer blending literary fiction with suspense, particularly when it come to motherhood.

I devoured the first 50ish pages of this story! It started off quick: you learn about the different women in the neighborhood, their marriage, lives, etc. We also get a glimpse of this party where one of these women, Whitney, yells at your 10 year old son, Xavier— an incident everyone a the party witnesses. A few months later, Xavier falls from his bedroom window in the middle of the night and the mystery behind what happened becomes the gossip of the neighborhood.

This story is told in alternating POVs from four of the women on the street. While it was interesting to gain insight into each of their homes and lives, I’ll be honest that at some points I felt like my interest wained and I found myself just not as invested into the story and happenings that were occurring in each home.

There’s definitely a lot of complexity to this story though, especially when it came to motherhood. Each women’s story was different yet seemed depict the dark side of what it’s like being not only a mother, but also a spouse. We see how each of these women make different choices and how those choices impact their lives, the people around them, and intertwine with the other women.

This definitely felt a bit more character driven versus plot driven, which I don’t mind! But there were definitely moments were I wanted this story to grip me, but it just didn’t. Ultimately, though story still revolves around the mystery of what happened to Xavier that horrific night that he fell. And towards the end, it did read at a quicker pace and the ending had some revelations and an ending that will leave you befuddled.

I still have some fairly mixed thoughts on this one. The characters weren’t likable, there were some topics that were tough to read about, but at the same time the writing was well done and kept you hooked enough to finish. Overall I’d say my feelings fall right in the middle!

Rating: 3/5

⚠️ Miscarriage & infertility are a big topic in this book and some of the scene are pretty graphic.

MIXED SIGNALS - Book review!

This is the the third installment of the beloved LOVELIGHT series and I personally think it may have been my favorite one yet!

We have already gotten glimpses to both Layla and Caleb in previous stories and I was so excited to finally read their romance and it makes me happy that it was everything I had hoped!

Being transported back into Inglewood was such a joy because I have always loved the vibes and that small town feel and community. And of course we get plenty of appearances from some favorites like Stella & Luka and Beckett & Evie. Now, for Layla and Caleb, I did like their romance from the start! From the Hawaiian shirt to the month-long deal agreement to date each other, to the failed dates, sweet moments, and everything in between— I adored it!

I also really liked both characters individually. Personally, I felt Layla’s personality and story to be the most relatable to myself which is why I think this story resonated with me more than the others. And then there was Caleb who, while kind of a pushover at times, was so sweet and thoughtful and I loved seeing how he treated Layla.

While their relationship definitely had its share of complications and well… mixed signals, I enjoyed seeing them both grow and become better versions of themselves and in turn make their relationship better. It was so easy to root for the two of them and overall it was just a feel-good type of read.

Also, this book seriously made me want to bake and eat so many delicious treats from cookies to cakes to croissants. So be prepared to go into this one craving all the baked goods!

Anyway, I can’t wait to eventually be back in Inglewood for Nova and Charlie’s story!

Rating: 4/5

DROWNING – Book review!

My latest bookstagram influenced reads!

The premise of this story is very unique and like one I haven’t quite read before which always makes things fun. Essentially, a commercial plane crashes into the ocean about 6 minutes into flight. Many people abandon the downed plane, but a group of 12 people remain onboard inside the aircraft as the plane sinks underwater. With only a few hours of oxygen left, the remaining survivors fight for their lives beneath the surface while a team above ground is simultaneously doing everything they can to save them.

Right from the start, this story was filled with action and entertainment! The pacing was quick which made for an addicting read because it was almost impossible to put down once you started. I found myself immersed into the story and just so curious as to how everything would transpire and how the survival and rescue mission would go. Reading about the different characters and their behavior and action in this life or death scenario was fascinating because it made you really wonder about the perseverance and what you would do.

Despite how compelling it was, there were still a few things that I struggled with. While I really appreciate the detail and behind the scenes of the plane itself, the training and nuances of being a part of the flight crew, etc., a lot of the writing still felt very technical where it took me out of the story a bit. Another thing was that I found there to be a few too many characters that it became hard to keep track of all the side characters and their roles. My last little struggle was with the MCs themselves, primarily Will. Of course I cannot imagine being stuck in life or death, survival scenario, but there were some actions and things he said that almost rubbed me the wrong way and made me not be a huge fan of him.

Overall though, this was still one enjoyable and adrenaline fueled read! Plus it made me go down the wormhole of incredible recovery missions such as the Thailand Cave Rescue from a few years ago. It also really made you thing and wonder how you would handle being in this type of situation and what type of role you would play in it!

Rating: 3/5

EMMA OF 83RD STREET - Book review!

This book is a modern day retelling of Jane Austen’s classic novel, EMMA. To be honest, I have never read that classic and didn’t even know too much about the premise, so some aspects of this retelling made me go “hmm” before realizing that it truly was mimicking the original. 

The Emma in this story comes from a wealthy family, a tight knit Upper East Side neighborhood, is currently in a graduate program, considers herself a matchmaker, and seems to innocently meddle into other people’s lives because she truly believes she’s helping. Her character was one I did struggle with at the beginning because I was not expecting, but after reading up on the original Emma, I learned that this is kind of the point. Emma is supposed to be a complicated heroine who grows and has self discovery throughout the course of the story. Once I knew this, everything made a lot more sense!

Then there’s the romance piece of the plot involving one of Emma’s childhood friends and neighbor, George Knightley. Knightley is a few years older than Emma and has always seen her more like a kid sister, but know that they’re older and both adults, he’s seeing her in a brand new light. For the most part, I did enjoy the romance because I think childhood friends to lovers is always such a sweet trope! While the romance was a bit of a slow-burn and there were a ton of moments I was wanted to yell at both Emma and Knightley to just talk, I did appreciate how there wasn’t really a third act breakup— something I almost find refreshing for romances!

Though Emma’s character did experience some growth, in some ways I was hoping for more because I felt like there was an opportunity to dig a little deeper as a lot of it felt surface level.

Overall, this was a cute, modern romance that was an easy read. I enjoyed the dual POV as well as the found family aspect of the neighborhood and seeing Emma and Knightly’s romance bloom. Still tbd if I will ever read the classic, but maybe one day!

Rating: 3.5/5

THE ONLY ONE LEFT - Mini book review!

Coming in this holiday Monday with some overdue thoughts on Riley Sager’s latest summer release!

I haven’t really jived with the last couple Sager books, so I was so happy that I actually enjoyed this one and feel like this was more reminiscent of his earlier books that I loved!

While this did still have the unreliable narrator trope, I was thoroughly entertained while reading and trying to figure out what was happening. I did have some hunches about where the story headed, but was still a bit surprised by some of the twists so was happy about that!

I also liked the dual perspectives and timelines, though I did find the one in the past to be just a bit more interesting.

Overall I was satisfied with this thriller! Still isn’t my favorite Sager (it’s probably The Last Time I Lied!), but was solid.

Rating: 4/5

THE WAKE-UP CALL - Book review!

I typically love Beth O’Leary books and will read anything she writes, so I was very excited about her upcoming book! The plot sounded super cute, but I was disappointed that this book ended up being a miss for me.

I’ll start with what I liked. Firstly, the quaint countryside hotel vibes paired with its sweet owners and the small group of guests and employees was charming. I also liked the idea behind the premise: two employees race to find the owners of lost rings so they can (hopefully) get a reward to help save the hotel from going out of business. It was sweet and provided good commentary on the past and starting fresh. Lastly, I did appreciate both backstories for our MCs, Izzy and Lucas. They’ve both dealt with grief and belonging, but show how vastly different they carry themselves.

What I hard time with was Izzy and Lucas’ romance. This was a workplace, enemies to lovers romance which in theory sounds like something I’d like! But the execution of it was not my favorite.

For starters, I wasn’t a fan of their reasonings to hate each other. It felt a little immature for two grown adults and I really disliked how they just avoided each other and made rash assumptions. And the way they behaved around others, forcing innocent people to have to step into their feuds was weird to me. Sure, some of this was addressed at the end of the story, but it just seemed too far fetched for me and by the time the explanations and apologies came around, I was already over it.

There was also something about the writing and POVs of our characters that grated on me and felt repetitive. Like during Izzy’s chapters, we were always reminded of how broody and muscular Lucas was. Also being that the POVs were in first person perspective, I found their thoughts and views (mostly Izzy’s) to be super frustrating at times.

Overall, I’m sad this didn’t quite work out for me, but I can see how others may enjoy it more than I did!

Rating: 3/5

Not my favorite spread, but I finished it which is always an achievement in itself! It’s now been THREE full months that I’ve successfully kept up with a bujo and I’m pretty dang proud of myself for that because this is by far the longest I’ve been consistent with journaling! And I do love it 🥹

THE SPECTACULAR - Book club review!

A bit behind, but sharing July’s pick! Fiona Davis was a new author to most, she is definitely one that everyone will read more of!

The book is set in New York during the 50s, a time when the infamous Big Apple Bomber was inciting fear in the city. The story follows Marion, a 19 year old who leaves behind the safe life her father wants of her and instead pursues her dream of the arts like her late mother, and lands herself a spot as a Radio City Rockette. As Marion gains more independence, she finds herself befriending a doctor named Peter and the two become involved in the search for the Big Apple Bomber thanks to Peter’s interest in profiling.

While being a historical fiction at its core, this book also blended other genres like mystery + coming of age. It was fun to see Marion make her own choices and become independent from her family. But also, you saw the struggles she faced with the pressure from her father to follow the “safe” route in life instead of following her heart.

As for the historical aspect, everyone really loved learning more about the Rockettes and learning more about the behind the scenes of the infamous group, especially in its early days. Secondly, it was fascinating to learn more about the Big Apple Bomber and how that case was one of the firsts to use criminal profiling to find the perpetrator. A lot of the details and story around the case were accurately portrayed in this story which made it even more interesting!

This story also had a lot of emotional moments within its pages particularly when it come to themes surrounding family. The 50s were a bit of a different time when it came to the expectation and roles of men and women and this book definitely depicted that at times.

The reason for pause is that even though this is still fiction and creative liberties are to be expected, the ending felt a bit over the top and you really had to suspend disbelief. Also after the Big Apple Bomber case is resolved, the story still went on for another 50ish photos where it did feel like it dragged a tad.

Overall though, this was enjoyed by all and was a great choice and book to discuss!

Group rating: 4/5

BLACK SHEEP - Book review!

Well, I can certainly say that I don’t think I have ever read a book quite like this before! It was my first by this author and it definitely seems to fall into that niche category of “weird” lit, but it also had horror, dark comedy, and satirical vibes to it as well!

Our MC, Vesper, ran away from home and her small town because she no longer wanted to be a part of the deeply religious community she grew up in. Six years later, Vesper is working as a waitress and just making ends meet when she receives an invite to her cousin’s wedding back in her hometown. What comes of all this are some dark secrets, a very dysfunctional family, some horror, and some laughs.

It’s hard to really say too much about this story without giving anything away, but I will say it’s best to go into it fairly blind aside from the basic premise! Because there was a bit of a surprise that happened around the 50 page mark that will make the story way more fun if you don’t already know it’s coming. I personally was taken aback by it that I had to read it twice and be like “wow this author went there!”, but in the most complimenting way!

As we learned more about Vesper, her past, and the events of the present day, the story just flew by and was so entertaining that it was hard to stop reading. While it was unique and outrageous in its own way, I did also appreciate how it brought up topics such as small towns with distinct ideologies, family, becoming your own person, and more.

Plus the ending of this one was just wild! There were so many moments where I was thinking to myself “is this really happening?!”. 

Overall, I enjoyed this more than I had expected and would recommend for the fall and spooky season if you’re looking for something a little bit weird and culty, but with a creative and highly entertaining story, then you should this one out!

Rating: 4/5
