THE WISHING GAME - Book review!

I had seen it compared to Willy Wonka and after finishing it, I can see why that is the case.

For her entire childhood our MC, Lucy, was unloved by her family. Her solace as the children’s book series, Clock Island, by Jack Masterson. She is now 26 years old, working as a teacher’s aide in California, after having left her home state of Maine. At the school she has formed a close connection with a 7 year old foster child, Christopher. The two have made wishes that Lucy formally adopt him and that may come true after Lucy is invited to participate in a game on the real Clock Island, hosted by the recluse, Jack Masterson himself.

For starters, I found the premise of this idea fun and charming. Jack is very much modeled like Willy Wonka and while he did seem genuine in wanting to help children out of dark places, something also felt off for me. Clock Island though was a charming place and I loved the message of how books can really be an escape. The game itself was full of riddles and fun, albeit a bit simplistic and rushed through.

There was also Hugo, the illustrator who redesigned the covers of the series. He has been at Jack’s side on the island for 13 years, but finds himself wanting more out of life outside the island. Hugo is English and grumpy, but also artistic, thoughtful, and funny. He was a fun character and I liked him as an individual, however…

I wasn’t a fun of the romance storyline with him and Lucy. They first met when she was 13 and he 21 (though nothing happened) and now after meeting again as adults their infatuation with each other was icky and I don’t think that plot line was necessary.

I also was not a fan of Lucy. She started off fine, but then as the story progressed her character started to bother me and I never found myself rooting for her. Lastly, while I understand why there is trauma in this story, it also felt like the author threw in every difficult topic, which became a bit cumbersome.

Overall, it was a quick read and I did appreciate how it discussed the foster care system. However, I did have high hopes for this and sadly it still fell a little flat.

Rating: 3/5

BABEL: AN ARCANE HISTORY – Book review!

I read this last month and it was probably my favorite book of August! And now a month later, I still don’t think I have the words to succinctly write a review for how special this book is. Part magical realism, part historical fiction, part dark academia, this book covered so much.

Firstly, this definitely one of those books where the writing is so beautiful and insightful that you just have to slowly savor to truly appreciate it. A huge component of this book is about Babel and how it’s academic focus is linguistics and translation and that in itself was incredibly fascinating to read and learn about, particularly in the context of the overall story.

There was also the dark academia angle too which I of course enjoyed. While the story is told from the perspective of one Babel academic, Robin, you get to experience everything through his eyes. Like with many books of this genre, there was the interesting dynamics amongst the small cohort of students within Babel. From friendship to rivalries and betrayals to underground societies, things got quite complicated at times, BUT it made for such an entertaining read!

The other big themes brought up were racism and colonialism. The latter of which is a topic that I can honestly say I have not read of outside of school textbooks, but RFK wrote about it in such a perceptive and clever way that it really made you think about those historical times when colonization was at it’s peak. Because of this, it brought up so many other discussions around things like race and power. My only minor criticism is that there were times where I wished the message was a bit more subtle instead of being so blatant. But again, just a minor thing.

While this book may seem daunting and dense to read and may not necessarily be or everyone, I am so glad I (finally) got around to it! It was just so well done and even created a range of emotions from frustration, heartbreak, and more. This was my second book by this author (after YELLOWFACE I made it a priority to read more) and I can honestly say that I’m a fan of her work and am eager to see what she puts out next!

Rating: 4.5/5

THE FURY - Book review!

Alex Michaelides is back with a new thriller and I have to say it did feel a bit different than his past work… and in an exciting and fun way!

This story definitely has more of a locked room, murder mystery/ whodunnit vibes that even has lots of references and pays homage to Agatha Christie. Plus there was a quirky and very unreliable narrator which made things interesting because it truly became difficult to know what to believe and who to trust as the story progressed and more details emerged.

Essentially the premise follows a group of wealthy and artistic friends to a private Greek island where soon after arrival, one of them ends up dead. There’s only so many people who could’ve committed the act so the mystery of who and why becomes the overarching plot.

I did find the story to be a bit slow in the beginning, primarily because it was introducing each of the characters and their relationships with each other and describing the day-to-day events leading up to the island stay as well as what occurred leading up to the murder. It totally made sense to build up the foundation, but I just find there to be a lack of action which made for a slow burn.

However, as mentioned above, there was an unreliable narrator and I do think his narrative helped keep things exciting because it felt like you knew where things were headed and then all of a sudden he would pivot in another direction and totally change course which made you second guess everything.

And then there was the ending which was quite explosive and wild that it felt like whiplash… if there was a good kind of whiplash! So many revelations came out and the truth around everything became apparent and it was just smartly executed that it had me going “ooooh!”.

Overall, this was a fine read that bordered on a tragic love story. A tad slow, but if you stick with it, you might just find the ending worth it. Plus the Greek island setting was fun and there are a couple of tiny throwbacks to characters in both of Michaelides’ previous books which are always fun little easter eggs!

Rating: 4/5

WITCH OF WILD THINGS - Book review!

Hello, if you are in need of a fun witchy book with some magical vibes, themes of sisterhood, horticulture galore, and a sprinkle of romance, then look no further at this book, PERFECT for the fall season!

The story follows Sage Flores, a young woman who’s family was supposedly cursed years ago and as a result, all the Flores woman are give a touch of magic and they each possess their own unique abilities. This part very much reminded me of Encanto, right down to the powers they had. And I loved Encanto, so that’s saying something!

Anywho, Sage is our MC and we follow her through her journey of love, forgiveness, and identity and it was a heartwarming story. Firstly, there’s the ghost of her younger sister Sky, who tragically passed eight years ago. Sage has been trying to figure out who to get Sky’s ghost peace and learns that in order to do so, she must talk and heal the fraught relationship she has with her other younger sister, Teal. This subplot definitely explores many topics such as grief, guilt, and more and was done in its own unique way by weaving in these fun magical elements.

There was also the romance angle too. While there were some parts that I liked— for example the throwback to instant messenger with the funky screen names— there were also a few things I wasn’t a huge fan of. Namely the fact that Sage withheld info from her love interest, Tennessee. But ultimately their work adventures together in botany and the second chance trope made for a sweet enough story.

While this may not have been groundbreaking in any ways, if you are just looking for a quick fall read, this may just do the trick!

Rating: 3/5

ARISTOTLE AND DANTE DISCOVER THE SECRETS OF THE UNIVERSE - Book club review!

For our September book club pick, we went this backlist YA book that recently became a movie!

The story follows two teenage boys in 1980s Texas and their friendship, self discovery/ growth, family life, and more. It’s very much your typical coming of age book as it was filled with hardships and some anguish, but also had its moment of pure tenderness and warmth.

One thing to note is this book is much more character vs. plot driven as it very much focuses on the development and relationship of both Ari and Dante and how the events that occur play a pivotal role in shaping them. Of course there’s absolutely nothing wrong with books that are more character based, but I do know that some people may not vibe as much with that and much prefer stories where there is a known plot. So like with many books, this factor may dictate how one person enjoys it over another!

Back to the book, we did all enjoy reading the story from Ari’s perspective because even though it is one that none of us could directly relate to, reading it still gave us so much more understanding to the internal conflicts of a young teen grasping with his identity. It was written in such a way where Ari and Dante’s emotions and everything happening felt so poignant and raw that it made for more powerful moments.

Another thing that everyone did really appreciate about this story was just how awesome and supportive the parents of both Ari and Dante were. While the story also depicted some of the struggles of the family dynamics, it showed the importance of having really amazing parents and there were scenes that were very heartwarming to read about.

Ratings amongst everyone varied between around 3-4.5 and shows just how subjective reading is!!

MISERY – Book review! And my first King in two years!
 
Quick little blurb for those unfamiliar: Best selling novelist of the Misery Chastain series, Paul Sheldon, is in a car accident, but saved by his number one fan and nurse, Annie Wilkes. Annie takes Paul back to her isolated Colorado home where she nurses him back to health, but upon hearing that Misery has been killed off in the latest novel, she forces Paul to write another story bringing Misery back to life.
 
I feel like this book made me so anxious because it read from Paul’s POV and the whole time you just had no idea what Annie was up to. Plus her moods were so unpredictable that one minute she could be fine and the next, she was on a rampage and when she was on one, you never knew what she might do! While I knew this book was going to be creepy heading in, some of Annie’s actions and cruelty still took me by surprise!
 
I also found this story to just be so well done and clever for different reasons. One being that there really only were two characters throughout the entirety of this book: Paul and Annie. Both were well developed and even though it was just two characters, the story still moved at such a good pace and it never felt stale and like you needed something more. Plus there was also the psychological aspect from Paul’s perspective as he was being held captive and tortured (in various ways) on top of being forced to write a Misery story to Annie’s satisfaction. A decent chunk of the book was in Paul’s head and getting his thoughts and seeing his internal fight for survival was great.
 
There were some revelations in the later half of the book too, particularly about Annie, that was fascinating from a psychopathy standpoint. And then the ending was insanely explosive and most definitely not for the faint of heart as it had some pretty descriptive and gory scenes as you may expect.
 
While it did have its terrifying moments, I really didn’t find this book to be as scary as I thought it might be. It definitely spooked me at times though and I can 100% see why the movie adaption would be horrifying and I can say with certainty that I will steer clear of that!
 
Rating: 4/5

THE BROKEN GIRLS – Book club review!
 
This book was perfect for the spooky fall season because it blended a few different themes very nicely from thriller/ mystery and paranormal with hints of historical fiction and dark academia. The pacing made the story move along quickly and it was compelling enough to keep interest and want to see how everything panned out at the end.
 
This story alternated between two different timelines. One is in 1950 at the haunted grounds of Idlewild, a boarding school for young girls with seemingly nowhere else to go. During this time, there are four girls who room together and though they are all different with distinct personalities, they form a special bond. When one of them goes missing, the others make it their mission to find out what happened. The second timeline takes place 60+ years later. Fiona is a journalist who is still grieving the murder of her sister after her body was found dumped in the abandoned Idlewild property 20 years ago. Her killer was convicted, but after a mysterious person buys the Idlewild with plans to restore it, Fiona finds herself digging into the past and uncovering secrets from the 50s as well as about her sister’s case.
 
Both the timelines were interesting for their own reasons. With the girls in the boarding school, it was horrific to learn about their pasts and what led them there as well as just that time period. A significant part of the plot also discussed WWII and the atrocities of concentration camps and its survivors which was something that was unexpected heading in, but made a lasting impression. In the present day, it was fun following Fiona as she learned more about the happenings at both Idlewild and within her small town, particularly when it come to corruption.
 
While certain aspects of the book were a tad predictable, there were still some surprises with just how intricate things were and how complicit some characters were when it came to events in the past.
 
Overall, this was the perfect read for the season with just the right amount of mix of everything. It wasn’t too scary at all, but still gave off those eerie vibes!
 
Group rating: 4/5

BRIGHT YOUNG WOMEN - Book review!

This book has received plenty of praise since its release, so that of course meant I had to push it up on my TBR!

This book was unique and chilling because it was such an interesting blend of true crime and fiction. It takes the horrors of Ted Bundy, one of the most notorious and prolific serial killers, but flips the script. Instead of the story being focused on him (as so many stories often are), it’s about the women who were his victims. So much so that the author chose to not once use his name, but instead referred to him solely as The Defendant, and I thought this spoke volumes! In some ways too, this book even felt like a character study of the many different women and people whose lives were irrevocably changed because of this one man.

The story was told in three different timelines: one in 1974 from the POV of Ruth who eventually becomes one of The Defendant’s victims in Washington state. Then there’s Pamela in 1978, a student and the sorority chapter president at FSU, who witnesses The Defendant leaving the house after murdering and injuring several of her sisters. And finally there’s Pamela in the present day of 2021. While each of their timelines were fascinating in their own way, I do have to say that Pamela’s 1978 POV was my favorite because I felt her character was written so well and I really appreciated her perspective.

While I did also like the story of Ruth and her relationship with Tina (who also appears in the other timelines), I did feel like there were jumps within those chapters and at times it made it difficult to keep track of what was happening. But Ruth’s story was also very powerful for its own reasons.

Overall I found this to be a super addicting and compelling read where I felt like I learned so much. It also creeped me out more than a lot of other books I’ve read, because of the fact it was all based off true events. Plus it totally sent me down the serial killer rabbit hole which probably didn’t help

If this sounds like something up your alley, I would definitely recommend!

Rating: 4/5

Thank you @bookclubfavorites for the gifted copy!

I’M GLAD MY MOM DIED - Book thoughts!

I’m sure many of you have seen enough reviews and praise for this memoir to know it’s about the relationship Jennette McCurdy had with her mother from childhood all the way until her mother’s passing when she was 21.

This memoir is heartbreaking, frustrating, yet brutally honest in its reflection of the events that occurred starting from when Jennette was just six years old. The first half of the memoir covers the “before” years of her mothers death and I found myself shocked at the things described, yet really appreciative of the candid way of which this was done. My heart broke for the younger Jennette who thought sacrificing her own happiness for her mother’s trumped everything. It is so sad to think about how she lost so many of those formative years in her childhood and never had that opportunity to just be a kid. Even as she continued to grow older, her mother played a pivotal role in everything including her eating habits, relationships, and more.

The second half of the memoir was also tough to stomach at times, but so so important because it covers some very dark topics such as grief, alcohol addiction, eating disorders, and overall mental health. It’s here where Jennette begins to truly come to terms with the full impact her mother's manipulation and abuse had and how all the ideas and comments she fed her throughout the years led Jennette to having a warped view of herself and how to approach life.

There were so many moments where her pain felt so visceral and I felt so angry at her mother for putting her through this. However, you begin to see the road to recovery and though its not pretty by any means, I appreciated the way this was written to show that it is an incredible challenge and one that will always be ongoing.

Overall, I highly recommend this memoir! It was also very accessible in the sense of it being very easy to read and follow along and not dense in any way. It read quickly and was super compelling throughout because let’s be real… human curiosity is a real thing it was just astounding to get a glimpse into this life story.

AN UNEXPECTED PATH - Book review & a very happy pub day to @authormegmcspadden !

So a few years ago, back in my baby bookstagram days, Meg and I connected about books of course, but also for our mutual love of ice hockey. Since then, not only have we chatted on many things, but Meg has now written a whole dang book! It’s been so cool seeing her writing journey and this amazing accomplishment!

This is a contemporary romance that includes things like: forced proximity, honest and lovable characters, lots of dogs including one named Yogurt, tension!, fall vibes, hilarious moments, emotional depth, and so much more.

One of the biggest standouts to me about this story were the characters in Marley and Bennett. They’re thrown together due to unforeseen circumstances  They each have their own backgrounds as well as struggles and I really admired the connection they had to be able to share their vulnerabilities and just communicate! — it made me love them even more! I also found so much value in the topics brought up around being a conflict photographer, PTSD, mental health, and the dangers of CTE. Nothing felt super forced, but just… authentic. While I was of course invested into the romance plot, I also found myself equally into both Marley and Bennett’s individual journey’s of healing and growth.

I also have to hand it to Meg for thawing my cold heart on the idea of insta-love. Historically it’s a trope that I’ve struggled with, but I knew and could appreciate heading in that this kind of love story is dear to her because of her own experiences! Usually I have a hard time because I just don’t feel that connection between love interests, but this one was done sooo well where it felt truly genuine where it didn’t seem that fast and you couldn’t help but root for Marley and Bennett!

Overall this felt like such a feel good and wholesome read! Plus it had some clever jokes and one-liners that had me giggling! I absolutely cannot wait to see what is next!

This debut is officially available today, so go out and support your indie authors and snag yourself a copy (physical or digital!) on Amazon now!

THE GLASS CASTLE - Book thoughts! Squeezing in this review before November ends!

I very much have been in the mood for some non fictions and memoirs lately so I figured it was time that I finally get my hands on this critically acclaimed memoir from Jeannette Walls!

This memoir tells the story of Jeannette’s upbringing from a young child and into adulthood. Her father was an alcoholic with a distrust in the government and typical societal norms, but was also very charismatic and dreamed big. Her mother was very distant from her children with her own aspirations of being an artist and almost seemingly blamed them for getting in the way of that.

There were so many heartbreaking moments mentioned during her childhood. From just the constant poverty they lived in primarily in part due to her parents’ choices in doing what they felt was “best” for the family. The good part out of this was the bond Jeannette had with her siblings and how they looked out for each other even during he hard times. They took on responsibilities most normal kids their ages would never do, but did to survive. On top of that, there were also stories of how Jeannette was exposed to sexual assault at a young age, but her parents turned a blind eye to it. It was absolutely devastating to read about and at moments wasn’t an easy read.

I think what really stood out to me though was how well written this memoir was. Despite the struggles she (and her siblings) experienced during their childhood and adolescence, Jeannette did such an amazing job of really creating that juxtaposition between love and anger towards her parents. As an outsiders, it can be easy to look at this family and be infuriated with the way the parents behaved and raised their kids. But the way Jeannette tells it, you can still sense there is a lot of love there and that things really can be complicate when it comes to family.

Lastly, I found the part taking place in NYC to be fascinating, especially when it came to her parents and their lifestyle. It was just shocking to read, but ultimately it was also amazing to see how Jeannette and her siblings grew into their own person.

Overall I highly suggest this memoir!

Happy Sunday! Sharing some mini reviews of a few holiday books I’ve read recently!

FAKING CHRISTMAS - A cute Christmas romance that includes fake dating + enemies to lovers! There’s also a bit of dysfunctional family element going on here that made things fun and kept me on my toes. The farm setting was dreamy and there were so many wonderful and cozy vibes and laughable moments that made this a nice holiday read. My biggest issue was that the miscommunication was dragged the heck out, primarily because our FMC, Laurel, refused to listen/ talk to the MMC, Max. But I did appreciate that there was no third act breakup! Though you have to suspend some disbelief, overall this was a quick and fun read! Rating: 3/5

BRIGHT LIGHTS, BIG CHRISTMAS - Another quick holiday read that involves a small town girl in NYC. There’s a small family run tree stand, an old camper van named Spammy, an eclectic mix of neighbors, some sibling tension, turf wars, and more! This story just exuded all the cozy Christmas vibes and I loved following our MC’s journey in working with her distant brother to run the family business for her first time. She experiences friendship, love, rediscovers her passion for art, and just grows as a person. While a tad cheesy, this book really encapsulated the joy of the holidays + had some heartwarming found family vibes! Rating: 4/5

UNLEASHED HOLIDAY - So. Many. Dogs! While categorized as a holiday, this one doesn’t solely cover the winter festivities, but starts in October so includes Halloween, Thanksgiving, with Christmas being the finale! The premise was cute with enemies with a past history who are now rival business owners. There’s also some chaotic family dynamics, mean and sassy goats, and even themes of grief. The main issue I had with it was similar to what was said in the first book review. I know miscommunication is pretty par for the course in contemporary romances, but I hate when that causes an MC to be rude and judgmental based of those preconceived notions. Overall though, just another standard holiday read to get you in the mood for the season! Rating: 3/5

FINLAY DONOVAN ROLLS THE DICE – Book review!

All you Finlay (and Vero) fans best get excited because our favorite and wild duo is back with this latest installment of the series!

This picks up where the third left off and we are thrust back into the world of the Russian mafia, loan sharks, dirty cops, and more. The general premise is that “girls” trip to Atlantic City to tie up some loose ends turns into a crazy adventure once the getaway turns into a family affair and police investigation.

Admittedly, I felt myself slightly losing some interest in the last book of this series, BUT I am so happy that this fourth one really established my love for Finlay and all the hilarious antics and situations she finds herself in. While you of course have to suspend disbelief, I think a lot of the fun in it is how outrageous the scenarios are and its such a funny and feel-good kind of read with some added mystery and suspense to it.

The Atlantic City setting of this particular story really did make for a fun time because it was filled with casinos, gambling, (more) dead guys, one memorable time in Chubbie, a dog named Kevin Bacon, and more over the top shenanigans. While there was a lot going in, I did love how it kept me guessing as to how everything was connected with the events of the previous stories and it was cool seeing how other little details reappeared to tie things together.

While the ending did wrap up quite a few of the storylines, it also did leave one little cliffhanger so it definitely seems like there will be more to come! And if you have not yet checked out this series and murder mysteries are your thing… what are you waiting for?

Rating: 4/5

Thank you @minotaurbooks for the gifted copy of this highly anticipated read! Officially out 3/5/24!

THE HEIRESS – Book review!

The latest from author, Rachel Hawkins, and I think this miiight just be my new favorite of hers! If stories about rich families with messed up dynamics particularly when it comes to inheritance and “what is rightfully theirs”, than this may be a book for you.

The eeriness of the story is set early on with the kidnapping and return of three year old, Ruby McTavish, in a small North Carolina town near the Appalachians. Ruby is the heiress to the great McTavish family fortune and lived quite a life until her death. In the present, Camden is summoned back to his childhood home to deal with the family he cut off all relations with and who despise him back. He brings along his wife, Jules, for support and their visit is the catalyst to unveiling long hidden secrets about different individuals and the family as a whole.

One thing I really enjoyed about this book was the different POVs and formats included. Not only do we get dual perspectives from both Camden and Jules, but we also get newspaper articles/ clippings from decades ago as well as more recently, and finally there are letters written by Ruby prior to her death that explain much of her past actions and why she did certain things. All of these different narratives and format did create a cohesive and engaging story that had me continually curious and wanting more. It helped that this also read SUPER quickly and was very easy to binge.

The atmosphere was also done well because the setting of the mansion created a sense of mystery where you just knew something was off. Learning about the different dynamics and drama of the McTavish family was fascinating and I like how the author used certain characters to contrast against each other to show who genuinely had good morals vs. those who did not.

There were many twists and while some were not a huge shock, I did find that others were more well done where it caught me off guard!

Overall, I thought this was a pretty solid thriller and if you love ones that you can read in a single sitting, you will want to check this out when it releases tomorrow 1/9! Thank you @stmartinspress for the gifted digital copy!

Rating 4/5
